the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Former seal of Gaithersburg, when it was a town]]

Gaithersburg has an elected, five-member City Council, which serves as the legislative body of the city. The Mayor, who is also elected, serves as president of the council. The day-to-day administration of the City is overseen by a career [[City Manager]]. Gaithersburg is also the location of the [[220th Military Police Brigade (United States)
the Greek myth: 220th Military Police Brigade]] of the [[United States Army Reserve]].

The city's current mayor is Jud Ashman, who has held the office since 2014. On October 6, 2014, the Gaithersburg City Council selected City Council Member Jud Ashman to serve as mayor until the next City of Gaithersburg election in November 2015, replacing resigning mayor [[Sidney A. Katz
the Greek myth: Sidney Katz]]. Ashman  was re-elected in November 2015.<ref>{{cite web
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=Council Member Jud Ashman Selected as Mayor of Gaithersburg

The departments of the city of Gaithersburg and their directors include:
* Office of the City Manager, Tony Tomasello
* Planning and Code Administration, John Schlichting
* Community and Public Relations, Britta Monaco
* Parks, Recreation, and Culture, Michele Potter
Being a city, Gaithersburg also has its own police department, which was created in 1963.<ref>{{Cite web

The Labours of Hercules}}: I-270 southbound at the interchange with I-370 in Gaithersburg]]

The most prominent highways serving Gaithersburg are [[Interstate 270 (Maryland)
the Greek myth: Interstate 270]] and [[Interstate 370]]. I-270 is the main highway leading northwest out of metropolitan Washington, D.C., beginning at [[Interstate 495 in Maryland
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Interstate 495]] (the Capital Beltway) and proceeding northwestward to [[Interstate 70 in Maryland
column5: Frederick]]. I-370 is a short spur, starting just west of I-270 in Gaithersburg and heading east to its junction with [[Maryland Route 200]]. Via MD 200, I-370 connects Gaithersburg with [[Interstate 95 in Maryland

[[Maryland Route 355]] was the precursor to I-270 and follows a parallel route. It now serves as the main commercial roadway through Gaithersburg and neighboring communities. Other state highways serving Gaithersburg include [[Maryland Route 117]], [[Maryland Route 119]] and [[Maryland Route 124]]. [[Maryland Route 28]] passes just outside the Gaithersburg corporate limits.

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: The Gaithersburg train station in January 2007]]

Gaithersburg is connected to the [[Washington Metro]] via [[Shady Grove (Washington Metro)
the Greek myth: Shady Grove station]], which is located just outside the city limits and is the north-western terminus of the [[Red Line (Washington Metro)

The [[Corridor Cities Transitway]] is a proposed [[bus rapid transit]] line that would have 8 stops in Gaithersburg, generally in the western half of the city.

the Greek myth: MARC]] system operates [[commuter rail]] services connecting Gaithersburg to [[Washington, D.C.]] with two stations in the city, at Old Town [[Gaithersburg (MARC station)
The Labours of Hercules}}: Metropolitan Grove]], and a third station — [[Washington Grove (MARC station)
column5: Washington Grove]] — just outside city limits.

Bus service in Gaithersburg consists of [[Metrobus (Washington, D.C.)
the Greek myth: Metrobus]] routes operated by [[Washington Metropolitan Area Transportation Authority
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: WMATA]] and [[Ride-On]] routes operated by [[Montgomery County, Maryland
The Labours of Hercules}}: Montgomery County]], as well as [[paratransit]] service provided by [[MetroAccess]].

The mainline of [[CSX Transportation]] bisects Montgomery County and runs as many as 50 trains a day through the center of Gaithersburg. The MARC trains run on the CSX tracks, as well as the [[Capitol Limited (Amtrak train)
the Greek myth: Capitol Limited]] from [[Amtrak]], through Gaithersburg but doesn't stop there though the train stops just over 5 miles away in Rockville.

The [[Montgomery County Airpark]] ([[IATA airport code]]: '''GAI''') is a short distance outside Gaithersburg city limits. The airport is the larger of two general aviation airports in the county.  For commercial airline service, Gaithersburg residents use [[Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport]], [[Washington Dulles International Airport]] or [[Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport

column5: accessdate=2013-01-25}}</ref> of 2010, there were 59,933 people, 22,000 households, and 14,548 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was {{convert
column9: 1}}. There were 23,337 housing units at an average density of {{convert
column13: 1}}. The racial makeup of the city was 31.9% non-Hispanic [[White (U.S. Census)
column19: other races]], and 4.8% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)
column21: Latino]] of any race were 24.2% of the population (8.3% Salvadoran, 2% Honduran, 1.9% Mexican, 1.9% Peruvian, 1.7% Guatemalan).

There were 22,000 households of which 37.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 48.3% were [[Marriage
the Greek myth: married couples]] living together, 12.7% had a female householder with no husband present, 5.1% had a male householder with no wife present, and 33.9% were non-families. 26.7% of all households were made up of individuals and 7.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.70 and the average family size was 3.24.

The median age in the city was 35.1 years. 24.2% of residents were under the age of 18; 7.9% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 33.8% were from 25 to 44; 24.6% were from 45 to 64; and 9.5% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.6% male and 51.4% females.

column5: title=U.S. Census website }}</ref> of 2000, there were 52,613 people, 19,621 households, and 12,577 families residing in the city. The [[population density]] was 5,216.2 people per square mile (2,013.3/km²). There were 20,674 housing units at an average density of 2,049.7 per square mile (791.1/km²). The racial makeup of the city is 34.7% [[White (U.S. Census)
column12: other races]], and 3.2% from two or more races. 24.8% of the population were [[Hispanics in the United States
column14: Latino]] of any race. 34.3% of Gaithersburg's population was foreign-born.

There were 19,621 households out of which 34.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 48.6% were married couples living together, 11.2% had a female householder with no husband present, and 35.9% were non-families. 27.8% of all households were made up of individuals and 7.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.65 and the average family size was 3.14

the population was spread out with 25.0% under the age of 18, 9.0% from 18 to 24, 37.7% from 25 to 44, 20.0% from 45 to 64, and 8.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females, there were 95.1 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 92.4 males.

the Greek myth: awards             = [[List of awards and nominations received by Ayushmann Khurrana

'''Ayushmann Khurrana''' (born '''Nishant Khurrana''' on 14 September 1984) is an Indian actor, singer, and television host. Known for his portrayals of ordinary men,<ref name=\"mint\">{{cite news
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Ayushmann Khurrana, actor of the year
column13: date=5 July 2019}}</ref> he is the recipient of [[List of awards and nominations received by Ayushmann Khurrana
column14: several awards]], including a [[National Film Award]] and four [[Filmfare Awards]], and has appeared in ''[[Forbes India]]''{{'s}} [[Forbes Celebrity 100

Khurrana won the second season of  reality television show [[MTV Roadies]] in 2004 and ventured into an anchoring career. He made his film debut in 2012 with the romantic comedy ''[[Vicky Donor]]'', in which his performance as a sperm donor earned him the [[Filmfare Award for Best Male Debut]].<ref>{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Ayushmann Khurrana reveals the most amusing comment he received for 'Shubh Mangal Savdhan'}}</ref><ref name=\"Vicky Donor HIT2\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> Following a brief setback, he starred in the commercially and critically successful romance ''[[Dum Laga Ke Haisha]]'' (2015). Khurrana went on to establish himself with the comedies ''[[Bareilly Ki Barfi]]'' (2017), ''[[Shubh Mangal Saavdhan]]'' (2017), ''[[Badhaai Ho]]'' (2018), ''[[Dream Girl (2019 film)
column10: Bala]]'' (2019); the thriller ''[[Andhadhun]]'' (2018); and the crime drama ''[[Article 15 (film)
column12: title=After Back-To-Back Hits, Ayushmann Khurrana Knows He's Become A Star But He Doesn't Want To Believe It
column16: date=21 October 2018}}</ref> Khurrana's performances as a blind pianist in ''Andhadhun'' and an honest cop in ''Article 15'' won him two consecutive [[Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor]], and he also won the [[National Film Award for Best Actor]] for the former.

In addition to acting, Khurrana has sung for several of his films, including the song \"[[Pani Da Rang]]\", which earned him the [[Filmfare Award for Best Male Playback Singer]].
Khurrana was born on 14 September 1984 in [[Chandigarh]] to Poonam and P. Khurrana,<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=I've evolved as an actor: Ayushmann Khurrana
column11: date=28 April 2013}}</ref> as Nishant Khurrana, later his parents changed his name to Ayushmann Khurrana when he was 3 years old. He was a part of Guru Nanak Khalsa College. He studied at [[St. John's High School, Chandigarh
column12: St. John's High School]] and [[DAV College, Chandigarh
column17: accessdate=5 June 2016}}</ref> He majored in [[English Literature
column18: English literature]] and has a master's degree in Mass Communication from the [[Panjab University
column19: School of Communication Studies, Punjab University]].<ref name=\"toifacts\">{{cite web
column20: title=Lesser known facts about Ayushmann Khurrana
column24: date=21 September 2015}}</ref> He did serious theatre for five years. He was also the founding member of DAV College's \"Aaghaaz\" and \"Manchtantra\", which are active theatre groups in Chandigarh.<ref name=\"toifacts\"/> He conceived and acted in street plays and won prizes in national college festivals such as [[Mood Indigo (festival)
column25: Mood Indigo]] ([[IIT Bombay]]), OASIS ([[Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani]]) and St. Bedes Shimla.<ref name=\"toifacts\"/> He also won a Best Actor award for playing [[Ashwatthama]] in [[Dharamvir Bharati]]'s [[Andha Yug]].<ref>{{cite web

Ayushmann Khurrana was noticed on TV at the age of 17. It was the reality show on Channel V; PopStars in 2002. He was one of the youngest contestants on the show. ''Roadies 5' took place in 2004 whereby he turned out to be the winner in ''Roadies 3'' at the age of 20.<ref name=\"City boy is MTV's most popular Roadie\">{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=City boy is MTV's most popular Roadie
column5: date=1 December 2004 }}</ref> After completing his graduation and post-graduation in Journalism, his first job was as an RJ at [[Big FM (Indian radio station)
column6: BIG FM]], [[Delhi]]. He hosted the show ''Big Chai – Maan Na Maan'', ''Main Tera Ayushmann'' and also won the Young Achievers Award in 2007 for it.<ref name=\" RJ Ayushmann Wins Young Achievers Award\">{{cite web
column8: title=RJ Ayushmann of BIG 92.7 FM creates history: Wins Young Achievers Award
column14: url-status=dead }}</ref> He was the youngest recipient of the Bharat Nirman Award in New Delhi.<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title = Ayushmann Khurrana – Ayushmann Khurrana Biography

He also worked in many other [[MTV India
the Greek myth: MTV]] shows such as ''MTV Fully Faltoo Movies'', ''Cheque De India'' and ''Jaadoo Ek Baar''.<ref name=\"MTV launches Three Films\">{{cite web
column6: date=10 September 2008}}</ref> He then turned television host with a multiple-talent based reality show [[India's Got Talent]] on [[Colors (TV channel)
column7: Colors TV]] which he co-anchored with   [[Nikhil Chinapa]] <ref name=\"Ayushman and Nikhil\">{{cite web
column9: title=In conversation with the host- Ayushman and Nikhil
column15: url-status=dead }}</ref> and ''Stripped'' which gave latest updates on the Indian TV industry with a comic tinge, again on [[MTV India
column16: MTV]]. At the end of the year, he was also the anchor of the singing reality show ''[[Music Ka Maha Muqqabla]]'' on [[STAR Plus]].<ref name=\"Ayushmann to host Music Ka Mahamuqabla\">{{cite web
column18: title=Ayushmann to host Music Ka Mahamuqabla

Apart from hosting the second season of ''[[MTV Rock On]]'' and ''[[India's Got Talent]]'' on [[Colors (TV channel)
the Greek myth: Colors]], Khurrana was also a part of the anchoring team of [[Indian Premier League

column9: title=Ayushmann Khurrana to host Superstar Buzz
column11: date=30 October 2010}}</ref> Following which he took up the offer of anchoring the dance-based reality show ''[[Just Dance (Indian TV series)

It marked the production debut of actor [[John Abraham]], and starred Khuranna in the titular role of a [[sperm donor]]. column6: title=Ayushmann's film debut as sperm donor

column23: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> With worldwide earnings of over {{INRConvert

column32: Best Male Debut]] and [[Filmfare Award for Best Male Playback Singer

column8: accessdate=20 December 2018 }}</ref> He then collaborated with [[Kunaal Roy Kapur]] in [[Rohan Sippy]]'s ''[[Nautanki Saala!]]'' (2013), a comedy based on the French film ''[[After You...
column9: Après Vous]]'' (2005). [[Anupama Chopra]] found Khurrana to be \"earnest\" in it but felt that his comedic work was overshadowed by that of Roy Kapur.<ref>{{cite news

column29: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', Andy Webster disliked the film's \"strained, contrived humor\" but commended Khurrana for \"holding his own opposite [Rishi] Kapoor\".<ref>{{cite news
column32: title=Boy Meets Girl; Boy Must Win Dad Over
column36: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> Both ''Nautanki Saala'' and ''Bewakoofiyaan'' were commercially unsuccessful, as was his next release, ''[[Hawaizaada]]'' (2015).<ref>{{cite news
column39: title=Ayushmann Khurrana: You are unlucky if you don't get setbacks
column43: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> In it, he played the scientist [[Shivkar Bapuji Talpade]], for which he lost weight and learnt to speak [[Marathi language
column47: title=Ayushmann Khurrana: Best part about being an actor is...
column51: accessdate=8 July 2019}}</ref> In the same year, Khurrana collaborated with his wife, Tahira Kashyap, to write his autobiography ''Cracking the Code: My Journey to Bollywood''.<ref>{{cite news
column54: title=Ayushmann Khurrana

Khurrana's career prospects improved when he starred opposite newcomer [[Bhumi Pednekar]] in the [[Sharat Katariya]] directed-romance ''[[Dum Laga Ke Haisha]]'' (2015).<ref name=\"decode\"/><ref>{{cite news
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=Ten hits that helped actors bounce back
column8: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> It tells the story of an underachieving man who is married against his will to an overweight woman. Anuj Kumar of ''[[The Hindu]]'' praised him for effectively capturing his character's \"diction and body language\".<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Ayushmann Khurrana: You are unlucky if you don't get setbacks
column15: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> Despite minimal promotions, the film emerged as a commercial success, grossing over {{INRConvert
column22: title=NH10 and more: Sleeper hits, a new trend in Bollywood

Two years later, after starring in the poorly received ''[[Meri Pyaari Bindu]]'', Khurrana's career progressed with his two other films releases of 2017, ''[[Bareilly Ki Barfi]]'' and ''[[Shubh Mangal Saavdhan]]'', both of which were commercially successful.<ref name=\"star\"/><ref name=\"decode\">{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Ayushmann Khurrana scores fourth success in a row with blockbuster Badhaai Ho – Decoding his superb run since Vicky Donor
column7: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> In the former, adapted from [[:it:Nicolas Barreau
column8: Nicolas Barreau]]'s French novel ''The Ingredients of Love'', he played alongside [[Rajkummar Rao]] and [[Kriti Sanon]] as a writer involved in a love triangle.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title=Bareilly Ki Barfi producers Abhay and Juno Chopra: We've inherited supporting a good stories
column13: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> Saibal Chatterjee of [[NDTV]] wrote that Khurrana does a \"convincing job of mutating from a brooding jilted lover to a crooked manipulator who puts his own interests above everyone else's\".<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Bareilly Ki Barfi Movie Review: Kriti Sanon Makes This Sweet Concoction Work
column23: df=dmy-all}}</ref> In ''Shubh Mangal Saavdhan'', he starred opposite Bhumi Pednekar as a newly engaged man suffering from [[erectile dysfunction]]. A remake of the Tamil film ''[[Kalyana Samayal Saadham]]'' (2013), the film, Khurrana hoped, would be a humorous take on mental and sexual problems faced by men which would bring wider attention to the topic.<ref>{{cite news
column26: title=Shubh Mangal Saavdhan: Nothing 'ashubh' about it
column29: accessdate=7 July 2019}}</ref> [[Rajeev Masand]] took note of how well the film handled sexuality without being crude and commended him for \"investing the fellow with genuine likeability and an understated charm\".<ref>{{cite web
column31: title=Shubh Mangal Saavdhan Review: One of This Year's Most Enjoyable Films
column35: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> Khurrana received a nomination for the [[Filmfare Award for Best Actor]] for the latter film.<ref>{{cite news

The Labours of Hercules}}: Khurrana accepting the 2019 [[National Film Award for Best Actor]] for his performance in ''[[Andhadhun]]'']]

In 2018, Khurrana starred in two of the [[List of Bollywood films of 2018
the Greek myth: highest-grossing Hindi films of the year]].<ref name=\"2018bo\">{{Cite web
column6: access-date=6 July 2019}}</ref> His first appearance was in [[Sriram Raghavan]]'s ''[[Andhadhun]]'', a thriller co-starring [[Tabu (actress)
column7: Tabu]] and [[Radhika Apte]], in which he played Aakash, a blind pianist who unwillingly becomes embroiled in a murder. He lobbied for the part after hearing about it from casting director [[Mukesh Chhabra]],<ref>{{cite news
column18: df=dmy-all}}</ref> and in preparation, he learnt how to play the piano and interacted with blind piano players.<ref>{{cite news
column22: title=Ayushmann Khurrana learns piano for Sriram Raghavan's thriller, Shoot the Piano Player
column30: title=Ayushmann Khurrana, Tabu poised to thrill in 'Andhadhun'
column40: Mint]]'' praised Khurrana for giving a \"taut performance that balances vulnerability with craftiness\" and Ankur Pathak of ''[[HuffPost]]'' found his to be \"a layered, no-holds-barred performance worth applauding\".<ref>{{cite news
column42: title=Andhadhun movie review: A twisted sight for sore eyes
column53: title=AndhaDhun Review: This Ayushmann Khurrana-Radhika Apte-Tabu Starrer Is The Best Film Of 2018 So Far
column54: last=Pathak
column60: b}} worldwide, a majority of which came from the Chinese box office, to become Khurrana's highest-grossing release and one of [[List of highest-grossing Indian films
column61: Indian cinema's biggest grossers]].<ref name=\"2018bo\"/><ref>{{cite web
column62: title=Top All Time All Format Worldwide Grossers - Andhadhun 13th
column66: accessdate=16 May 2019}}</ref> He next starred as Nakul Kaushik in ''[[Badhaai Ho]]'', a comedy from director [[Amit Sharma (director)
column67: Amit Ravindernath Sharma]] about a young man whose middle-aged parents get pregnant. [[Anna M. M. Vetticad]] of ''[[Firstpost]]'' considered his performance to be \"completely convincing\" and commended him for choosing \"to work in small films where the star is the story\".<ref>{{cite news
column69: title=Badhaai Ho movie review: Neena Gupta, Ayushmann Khurrana & Co redefine warmth in Sai Paranjpye/Basu Chatterjee style
column73: access-date=6 July 2019}}</ref> A [[sleeper hit]], it earned over {{INRConvert
column77: title=Badhaai Ho, The Surprise Bollywood Hit Of 2018
column81: access-date=6 July 2019}}</ref> For ''Andhadhun'', Khurrana won the [[National Film Award for Best Actor]] (shared with [[Vicky Kaushal]] for ''[[Uri: The Surgical Strike]]'') and the [[Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor]].<ref>{{cite news
column82: title=Winners of the 64th Vimal Filmfare Awards 2019
column88: title=National Film Awards 2019: 'Andhadhun', 'Uri:The Surgical Strike' bag awards
column91: date=9 August 2019}}</ref> Additionally, ''Badhaai Ho'' won the [[National Film Award for Best Popular Film Providing Wholesome Entertainment]].

The series of successful films continued with Khurrana's 2019 releases, ''[[Article 15 (film)
column6: title=Interview: Chameleon Cool Ayushmann Khurrana, the five-hits-in-a-row wonder
column12: title=Brand Ayushmann Khurrana races ahead of the competition
column15: access-date=12 November 2019}}</ref> In the formermost, a crime thriller directed by [[Anubhav Sinha]], he played the starring role of a righteous police officer solving a rape case. Highlighting [[Caste system in India
column16: caste discrimination in India]], the film was inspired by multiple events, including the [[2014 Badaun gang rape allegations]] and the [[Una Violence#Una incident
column19: title='Article 15' teaser: Ayushmann Khurrana's film on Badaun gangrape and murder is haunting
column23: title=Ayushmann Khurana's next 'Article 15' is inspired by true events!
column26: access-date=25 May 2019}}</ref> Khurrana agreed to the project to play a dark and intense character for the first time in his film career.<ref>{{cite news
column28: title='I keep the story before my character': Ayushmann Khurrana opens up on 'Article 15' and more
column32: access-date=6 July 2019}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The Guardian]]'', Wendy Ide commended him for \"combin[ing] soulful Bollywood heartthrob charisma with an arrestingly intense performance.\"<ref>{{cite news
column34: title=Article 15 review – no-holds-barred Indian crime thriller
column38: access-date=6 July 2019}}</ref> In the comedy ''Dream Girl'', he starred as Karamveer Singh, a [[cross-gender acting
column39: cross-gender actor]] who speaks in a female voice while working at a call centre which unwittingly attracts male attention.<ref>{{cite news
column42: title = ‘I want to explore more territories’: Ayushmann Khurrana
column45: access-date = 13 September 2019 }}</ref> Nandini Ramnath of [[Scroll.in]] considered his \"manic energy and believable Everyman persona\" to be the film's highlight.<ref>{{cite web
column48: title = ‘Dream Girl’ movie review: Ayushmann Khurrana is in fine form as the hero as well as the heroine
column51: access-date = 13 September 2019 }}</ref> His next release, ''Bala'', which marked his only non-singing screen appearance, was also a comedy, in which he played a young man who faces societal pressure due to premature balding. He found it physically challenging to play the part due to the heavy layers of prosthetics used on his head.<ref>{{cite news
column54: title = “Bala is the toughest film of my life” - Ayushmann Khurrana
column57: access-date = 12 November 2019 }}</ref> Rajeev Masand opined that Khurrana \"cuts a sympathetic figure as another not-instantly-likeable loser\" and added that he had \"cornered the market when it comes to playing flawed, insecure men with confidence issues\".<ref>{{cite web
column59: title=Bala Movie Review: Ayushmann Khurrana's Winning Streak Continues
column63: accessdate=12 November 2019}}</ref> He won another Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor for ''Article 15'' and received a Best Actor nomination at the ceremony for ''Bala''.<ref>{{cite news
column65: title=65th Amazon Filmfare Awards 2020 live updates
column72: accessdate=3 February 2020}}</ref> That year, he reappeared on ''Forbes India''{{'s}} Celebrity 100 list, ranking 37th with an estimated annual income of {{INRConvert

For his next project, Khurrana actively looked for another mainstream film that would portray sexuality in a humorous manner. He found it in ''[[Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan]]'' (2020), a spiritual successor to ''Shubh Mangal Saavdhan'' from the prequel's dialogue writer Hitesh Kewalya, in which he played a gay man, Kartik Singh, who has trouble convincing his partner's conservative family of their relationship.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title = I am dying to do a Rohit Shetty film - Ayushmann Khurrana
column8: access-date = 22 February 2020 }}</ref> Shubhra Gupta of ''[[The Indian Express]]'' credited Khurrana for \"allowing the film to be so much about\" his lesser known co-star [[Jitendra Kumar]].<ref>{{cite news
column12: title = Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan review: The chase of love
column15: access-date = 22 February 2020 }}</ref> Khurrana will next reunite with Shoojit Sircar for the comedy-drama ''[[Gulabo Sitabo]]'', co-starring [[Amitabh Bachchan]].<ref>{{cite news
column17: title = Ayushmann Khurrana on working with Amitabh Bachchan in Gulabo Sitabo: I have butterflies in my stomach
column22: title = Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan: Ayushmann Khurrana In A Gay Love Story

[[File:Ayushman Khurana walks for Manish Malhotra & Shaina NC's show for CPAA 23.jpg

Khurrana was born in [[Chandigarh]]. His father P Khurrana is an astrologer and an author on the subject of astrology, whereas his mother Poonam is a housewife and she is of half-Burmese descent<ref>{{cite news
column5: work=Bollywood Hungama}}</ref> and a qualified M.A. in Hindi{{Citation needed
column6: date=March 2016}}. While Ayushmann remains busy with his work in [[Mumbai]], his family still stays in Chandigarh. His brother [[Aparshakti Khurana]] is a radio jockey at Radio Mirchi 98.3 FM in Delhi and made his debut in the 2016 [[Aamir Khan]]-starrer film ''[[Dangal (film)
column9: title=Ayushmann Khurrana's brother to make debut in Dangal}}</ref><ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Ayushmann My brother is more like Vicky: Ayushmann Khurrana
column13: date=20 March 2014}}</ref> The ambiance of literature at home influenced Khurrana as well and he took writing as a hobby. He also maintains a blog where he writes in Hindi and it has been received very well by his admirers.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Hindi Hain Hum?}}</ref> Ayushmann is known for being very close to his family and wife, Tahira Kashyap, who has directed a critically acclaimed film Toffee. They are childhood sweethearts and are parents of a son and a daughter.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Ayushmann Khurrana: I had Rs 10,000 in my account when I got married
column21: title=Why Ayushmann Khurrana's Wife Tahira Kashyap Is Trending
column22: publisher=}}</ref> His son, Virajveer, was born on 2 January 2012 and his daughter, Varushka, was born on 21 April 2014.<ref>{{cite news
column24: title= It's a girl for Ayushmann Khurrana and wife Tahira!
column30: accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> In 2018, when he was promoting Badhaai Ho and Andhadhun, his wife Tahira was diagnosed with stage 0 breast cancer. Tahira's positive outlook helped them remain rock solid through this difficult phase.<ref>{{cite web

the Greek myth: List of awards and nominations received by Ayushmann Khurrana}}

column6: title=Cracking the Code: My Journey in Bollywood

[[Category:Best Actor National Film Award winners]]","{{short description

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Koffee With Karan 6: Karan Johar reveals his real name, Ayushmann Khuranna says his wife's father walked in on them

the Greek myth: awards             = [[List of awards and nominations received by Ayushmann Khurrana

'''Ayushmann Khurrana''' (born '''Nishant Khurrana''' on 14 September 1984) is an Indian actor, singer, and television host. Known for his portrayals of ordinary men,<ref name=\"mint\">{{cite news
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Ayushmann Khurrana, actor of the year
column13: date=5 July 2019}}</ref> he is the recipient of [[List of awards and nominations received by Ayushmann Khurrana
column14: several awards]], including a [[National Film Award]] and four [[Filmfare Awards]], and has appeared in ''[[Forbes India]]''{{'s}} [[Forbes Celebrity 100

Khurrana won the second season of  reality television show [[MTV Roadies]] in 2004 and ventured into an anchoring career. He made his film debut in 2012 with the romantic comedy ''[[Vicky Donor]]'', in which his performance as a sperm donor earned him the [[Filmfare Award for Best Male Debut]].<ref>{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Ayushmann Khurrana reveals the most amusing comment he received for 'Shubh Mangal Savdhan'}}</ref><ref name=\"Vicky Donor HIT2\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=2015-03-10}}</ref> Following a brief setback, he starred in the commercially and critically successful romance ''[[Dum Laga Ke Haisha]]'' (2015). Khurrana went on to establish himself with the comedies ''[[Bareilly Ki Barfi]]'' (2017), ''[[Shubh Mangal Saavdhan]]'' (2017), ''[[Badhaai Ho]]'' (2018), ''[[Dream Girl (2019 film)
column10: Bala]]'' (2019); the thriller ''[[Andhadhun]]'' (2018); and the crime drama ''[[Article 15 (film)
column12: title=After Back-To-Back Hits, Ayushmann Khurrana Knows He's Become A Star But He Doesn't Want To Believe It
column16: date=21 October 2018}}</ref> Khurrana's performances as a blind pianist in ''Andhadhun'' and an honest cop in ''Article 15'' won him two consecutive [[Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor]], and he also won the [[National Film Award for Best Actor]] for the former.

In addition to acting, Khurrana has sung for several of his films, including the song \"[[Pani Da Rang]]\", which earned him the [[Filmfare Award for Best Male Playback Singer]].
Khurrana was born on 14 September 1984 in [[Chandigarh]] to Poonam and P. Khurrana,<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=I've evolved as an actor: Ayushmann Khurrana
column11: date=28 April 2013}}</ref> as Nishant Khurrana, later his parents changed his name to Ayushmann Khurrana when he was 3 years old. He was a part of Guru Nanak Khalsa College. He studied at [[St. John's High School, Chandigarh
column12: St. John's High School]] and [[DAV College, Chandigarh
column17: accessdate=5 June 2016}}</ref> He majored in [[English Literature
column18: English literature]] and has a master's degree in Mass Communication from the [[Panjab University
column19: School of Communication Studies, Punjab University]].<ref name=\"toifacts\">{{cite web
column20: title=Lesser known facts about Ayushmann Khurrana
column24: date=21 September 2015}}</ref> He did serious theatre for five years. He was also the founding member of DAV College's \"Aaghaaz\" and \"Manchtantra\", which are active theatre groups in Chandigarh.<ref name=\"toifacts\"/> He conceived and acted in street plays and won prizes in national college festivals such as [[Mood Indigo (festival)
column25: Mood Indigo]] ([[IIT Bombay]]), OASIS ([[Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani]]) and St. Bedes Shimla.<ref name=\"toifacts\"/> He also won a Best Actor award for playing [[Ashwatthama]] in [[Dharamvir Bharati]]'s [[Andha Yug]].<ref>{{cite web

Ayushmann Khurrana was noticed on TV at the age of 17. It was the reality show on Channel V; PopStars in 2002. He was one of the youngest contestants on the show. ''Roadies 5' took place in 2004 whereby he turned out to be the winner in ''Roadies 3'' at the age of 20.<ref name=\"City boy is MTV's most popular Roadie\">{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=City boy is MTV's most popular Roadie
column5: date=1 December 2004 }}</ref> After completing his graduation and post-graduation in Journalism, his first job was as an RJ at [[Big FM (Indian radio station)
column6: BIG FM]], [[Delhi]]. He hosted the show ''Big Chai – Maan Na Maan'', ''Main Tera Ayushmann'' and also won the Young Achievers Award in 2007 for it.<ref name=\" RJ Ayushmann Wins Young Achievers Award\">{{cite web
column8: title=RJ Ayushmann of BIG 92.7 FM creates history: Wins Young Achievers Award
column14: url-status=dead }}</ref> He was the youngest recipient of the Bharat Nirman Award in New Delhi.<ref>{{Cite web
column15: title = Ayushmann Khurrana – Ayushmann Khurrana Biography

He also worked in many other [[MTV India
the Greek myth: MTV]] shows such as ''MTV Fully Faltoo Movies'', ''Cheque De India'' and ''Jaadoo Ek Baar''.<ref name=\"MTV launches Three Films\">{{cite web
column6: date=10 September 2008}}</ref> He then turned television host with a multiple-talent based reality show [[India's Got Talent]] on [[Colors (TV channel)
column7: Colors TV]] which he co-anchored with   [[Nikhil Chinapa]] <ref name=\"Ayushman and Nikhil\">{{cite web
column9: title=In conversation with the host- Ayushman and Nikhil
column15: url-status=dead }}</ref> and ''Stripped'' which gave latest updates on the Indian TV industry with a comic tinge, again on [[MTV India
column16: MTV]]. At the end of the year, he was also the anchor of the singing reality show ''[[Music Ka Maha Muqqabla]]'' on [[STAR Plus]].<ref name=\"Ayushmann to host Music Ka Mahamuqabla\">{{cite web
column18: title=Ayushmann to host Music Ka Mahamuqabla

Apart from hosting the second season of ''[[MTV Rock On]]'' and ''[[India's Got Talent]]'' on [[Colors (TV channel)
the Greek myth: Colors]], Khurrana was also a part of the anchoring team of [[Indian Premier League
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Extra Innings T20 for Indian Premier League Season 3]] on [[SET Max]] with Gaurav Kapur, [[Samir Kochhar]] , and Angad Bedi.<ref name=\"Max Unveils Extra Innings T20 for IPL 2010\">{{cite web
column5: title=Max Unveils Mega Extra Innings T20 for IPL 2010
column9: title=Ayushmann Khurrana to host Superstar Buzz
column11: date=30 October 2010}}</ref> Following which he took up the offer of anchoring the dance-based reality show ''[[Just Dance (Indian TV series)

column5: Khurrana at an event for ''[[Vicky Donor]]'' (2012), his film debut]]

Khurrana made his acting debut in 2012 with [[Shoojit Sircar]]'s romantic comedy ''[[Vicky Donor]]'', co-starring [[Annu Kapoor]] and [[Yami Gautam]]. It marked the production debut of actor [[John Abraham]], and starred Khuranna in the titular role of a [[sperm donor]]. In preparation, he attended acting workshops and interacted with medical professionals.<ref name=\"R1\">{{cite news
column6: title=Ayushmann's film debut as sperm donor
column9: url-status=dead}}</ref> For the film's soundtrack, he sang \"[[Pani Da Rang]]\", which he had written and composed with [[Rochak Kohli]] back in 2003.<ref>{{cite news
column12: title=I wrote 'pani da' in 2003 while in college: Ayushmann Khurrana
column16: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> Praising the film's ensemble cast, Sukanya Verma of [[Rediff.com]] wrote that Khurrana's \"candid disposition and roguish face ensures his street smart drollery works like a breeze\".<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Review: Vicky Donor is a pleasant surprise
column23: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> With worldwide earnings of over {{INRConvert
column27: m}}, ''Vicky Donor'' emerged as a commercial success.<ref>{{cite web
column31: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> At the [[Filmfare Awards]] ceremony, Khurrana was awarded trophies for [[Filmfare Award for Best Male Debut
column32: Best Male Debut]] and [[Filmfare Award for Best Male Playback Singer

In 2013, Khurrana appeared in ''[[Forbes India]]''{{'s}} [[Forbes Celebrity 100
the Greek myth: Celebrity 100]] list, ranking 70th with an estimated annual income of {{INRConvert
column8: accessdate=20 December 2018 }}</ref> He then collaborated with [[Kunaal Roy Kapur]] in [[Rohan Sippy]]'s ''[[Nautanki Saala!]]'' (2013), a comedy based on the French film ''[[After You...
column9: Après Vous]]'' (2005). [[Anupama Chopra]] found Khurrana to be \"earnest\" in it but felt that his comedic work was overshadowed by that of Roy Kapur.<ref>{{cite news
column16: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> He also recorded two songs for the film's soundtrack.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=Ayushmann records two songs for 'Nautanki Saala!'
column22: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> A year later, Khurrana teamed with [[Yash Raj Films]] (as part of a three-film deal) in the romantic comedy ''[[Bewakoofiyaan]]'' (2014), co-starring [[Sonam Kapoor]] and [[Rishi Kapoor]], about a young man who has trouble convincing his girlfriend's father to approve of their marriage.<ref>{{cite news
column29: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', Andy Webster disliked the film's \"strained, contrived humor\" but commended Khurrana for \"holding his own opposite [Rishi] Kapoor\".<ref>{{cite news
column32: title=Boy Meets Girl; Boy Must Win Dad Over
column36: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> Both ''Nautanki Saala'' and ''Bewakoofiyaan'' were commercially unsuccessful, as was his next release, ''[[Hawaizaada]]'' (2015).<ref>{{cite news
column39: title=Ayushmann Khurrana: You are unlucky if you don't get setbacks
column43: accessdate=6 July 2019}}</ref> In it, he played the scientist [[Shivkar Bapuji Talpade]], for which he lost weight and learnt to speak [[Marathi language
column47: title=Ayushmann Khurrana: Best part about being an actor is...
column51: accessdate=8 July 2019}}</ref> In the same year, Khurrana collaborated with his wife, Tahira Kashyap, to write his autobiography ''Cracking the Code: My Journey to Bollywood''.<ref>{{cite news
column54: title=Ayushmann Khurrana

Khurrana's career prospects improved when he starred opposite newcomer [[Bhumi Pednekar]] in the [[Sharat Katariya]] directed-romance ''[[Dum Laga Ke Haisha]]'' (2015).<ref name=\"decode\"/><ref>{{cite news

column88: title=National Film Awards 2019: 'Andhadhun', 'Uri:The Surgical Strike' bag awards

The series of successful films continued with Khurrana's 2019 releases, ''[[Article 15 (film)
column6: title=Interview: Chameleon Cool Ayushmann Khurrana, the five-hits-in-a-row wonder
column12: title=Brand Ayushmann Khurrana races ahead of the competition
column15: access-date=12 November 2019}}</ref> In the formermost, a crime thriller directed by [[Anubhav Sinha]], he played the starring role of a righteous police officer solving a rape case. Highlighting [[Caste system in India
column16: caste discrimination in India]], the film was inspired by multiple events, including the [[2014 Badaun gang rape allegations]] and the [[Una Violence#Una incident
column19: title='Article 15' teaser: Ayushmann Khurrana's film on Badaun gangrape and murder is haunting
column23: title=Ayushmann Khurana's next 'Article 15' is inspired by true events!
column26: access-date=25 May 2019}}</ref> Khurrana agreed to the project to play a dark and intense character for the first time in his film career.<ref>{{cite news
column28: title='I keep the story before my character': Ayushmann Khurrana opens up on 'Article 15' and more
column32: access-date=6 July 2019}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The Guardian]]'', Wendy Ide commended him for \"combin[ing] soulful Bollywood heartthrob charisma with an arrestingly intense performance.\"<ref>{{cite news
column34: title=Article 15 review – no-holds-barred Indian crime thriller
column38: access-date=6 July 2019}}</ref> In the comedy ''Dream Girl'', he starred as a [[cross-gender acting
column39: cross-gender actor]] who speaks in a female voice while working at a call centre which unwittingly attracts male attention.<ref>{{cite news
column42: title = ‘I want to explore more territories’: Ayushmann Khurrana
column45: access-date = 13 September 2019 }}</ref> Nandini Ramnath of [[Scroll.in]] considered his \"manic energy and believable Everyman persona\" to be the film's highlight.<ref>{{cite web
column48: title = ‘Dream Girl’ movie review: Ayushmann Khurrana is in fine form as the hero as well as the heroine
column51: access-date = 13 September 2019 }}</ref> His next release, ''Bala'', was also a comedy, in which he played a young man who faces societal pressure due to premature balding. He found it physically challenging to play the part due to the heavy layers of prosthetics used on his head.<ref>{{cite news
column54: title = “Bala is the toughest film of my life” - Ayushmann Khurrana
column57: access-date = 12 November 2019 }}</ref> Rajeev Masand opined that Khurrana \"cuts a sympathetic figure as another not-instantly-likeable loser\" and added that he had \"cornered the market when it comes to playing flawed, insecure men with confidence issues\".<ref>{{cite web
column59: title=Bala Movie Review: Ayushmann Khurrana's Winning Streak Continues
column63: accessdate=12 November 2019}}</ref> He won another Filmfare Critics Award for Best Actor for ''Article 15'' and received a Best Actor nomination at the ceremony for ''Bala''.<ref>{{cite news
column65: title=65th Amazon Filmfare Awards 2020 live updates
column72: accessdate=3 February 2020}}</ref> That year, he reappeared on ''Forbes India''{{'s}} Celebrity 100 list, ranking 37th with an estimated annual income of {{INRConvert

For his next project, Khurrana actively looked for another mainstream film that would portray sexuality in a humorous manner. He found it in ''[[Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan]]'' (2020), in which he played a gay man who has trouble convincing his partner's family of their relationship.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title = I am dying to do a Rohit Shetty film - Ayushmann Khurrana
column8: access-date = 22 February 2020 }}</ref> Shubhra Gupta of ''[[The Indian Express]]'' credited Khurrana for \"allowing the film to be so much about\" his lesser known co-star [[Jitendra Kumar]].<ref>{{cite news
column12: title = Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan review: The chase of love
column15: access-date = 22 February 2020 }}</ref> Khurrana will next reunite with Shoojit Sircar for the comedy-drama ''[[Gulabo Sitabo]]'', co-starring [[Amitabh Bachchan]].<ref>{{cite news
column17: title = Ayushmann Khurrana on working with Amitabh Bachchan in Gulabo Sitabo: I have butterflies in my stomach
column22: title = Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhan: Ayushmann Khurrana In A Gay Love Story

[[File:Ayushman Khurana walks for Manish Malhotra & Shaina NC's show for CPAA 23.jpg

Khurrana was born in [[Chandigarh]]. His father P Khurrana is an astrologer and an author on the subject of astrology, whereas his mother Poonam is a housewife and she is of half-Burmese descent<ref>{{cite news
column5: work=Bollywood Hungama}}</ref> and a qualified M.A. in Hindi{{Citation needed
column6: date=March 2016}}. While Ayushmann remains busy with his work in [[Mumbai]], his family still stays in Chandigarh. His brother [[Aparshakti Khurana]] is a radio jockey at Radio Mirchi 98.3 FM in Delhi and made his debut in the 2016 [[Aamir Khan]]-starrer film ''[[Dangal (film)
column9: title=Ayushmann Khurrana's brother to make debut in Dangal}}</ref><ref>{{cite news
column11: title=Ayushmann My brother is more like Vicky: Ayushmann Khurrana
column13: date=20 March 2014}}</ref> The ambiance of literature at home influenced Khurrana as well and he took writing as a hobby. He also maintains a blog where he writes in Hindi and it has been received very well by his admirers.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Hindi Hain Hum?}}</ref> Ayushmann is known for being very close to his family and wife, Tahira Kashyap, who has directed a critically acclaimed film Toffee. They are childhood sweethearts and are parents of a son and a daughter.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Ayushmann Khurrana: I had Rs 10,000 in my account when I got married
column21: title=Why Ayushmann Khurrana's Wife Tahira Kashyap Is Trending
column22: publisher=}}</ref> His son, Virajveer, was born on 2 January 2012 and his daughter, Varushka, was born on 21 April 2014.<ref>{{cite news
column24: title= It's a girl for Ayushmann Khurrana and wife Tahira!
column30: accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> In 2018, when he was promoting Badhaai Ho and Andhadhun, his wife Tahira was diagnosed with stage 0 breast cancer. Tahira's positive outlook helped them remain rock solid through this difficult phase.<ref>{{cite web

the Greek myth: List of awards and nominations received by Ayushmann Khurrana}}

MATP}} at the [[Massachusetts]] state line in [[Canaan, New York

'''Interstate 90''' ('''I-90''') is a part of the [[Interstate Highway System]] that runs from [[Seattle, Washington]], to [[Boston, Massachusetts]]. In the [[U.S. state]] of [[New York (state)
column6: Pennsylvania state line]] at [[Ripley, New York
column7: Ripley]] to the [[Massachusetts]] state line at [[Canaan, New York
column8: Canaan]], and is the second-longest highway in the state after [[New York State Route 17
column9: NY 17]]. Although most of the route is part of the tolled [[New York State Thruway]], two non-tolled sections exist along I-90 (the first, situated outside of Buffalo, is included in the Thruway system; the second, situated in the [[Capital District, New York
column10: Capital District]], is not part of the Thruway system and links [[Albany, New York
column11: Albany]] and its eastern suburbs). Within New York, I-90 has a complete set of auxiliary Interstates, which means that there are interstates numbered [[Interstate 190 (New York)
column13: I-990]] in the state, with no gaps in between. For most of its length in New York, I-90 runs parallel to the former [[Erie Canal]] route, [[New York State Route 5]] (NY 5), [[U.S. Route 20 in New York
column14: U.S. Route 20]] (US 20) and the [[CSX]] railroad mainline that traverses the state.

I-90 was assigned in 1957 as part of the establishment of the Interstate Highway System. In New York, it was overlaid on the pre-existing New York State Thruway from Pennsylvania to Albany, from where it would have continued to Massachusetts on a new freeway that bypassed the [[Berkshire Connector]] to the north. Ultimately, the freeway was built from the Thruway mainline in Albany to the Berkshire Connector in [[Schodack, New York
the Greek myth: Schodack]], and I-90 was assigned to the segment of the Connector east of the proposed freeway. The Albany–Schodack freeway was completed in stages during the 1960s and 1970s and fully open by 1977.
Albany]], I-90 in New York is designated along the mainline of the [[New York State Thruway]]. The Thruway begins at the [[New York–Pennsylvania border
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Pennsylvania state line]] in [[Chautauqua County, New York
The Labours of Hercules}}: Chautauqua County]], following the shore of [[Lake Erie]] northeast and passes through the town of [[Cheektowaga, New York
column5: Cheektowaga]], a large [[suburb]] of [[Buffalo, New York
column6: Buffalo]] directly east of the city. Two auxiliary routes, [[Interstate 190 (New York)
column8: Niagara Falls]] and connecting into Canada as [[Ontario Highway 405]]) and [[Interstate 290 (New York)
column9: I-290]] (a northerly bypass of Buffalo) connect with I-90 here. Both auxiliary routes provide access between I-90 and Canada's largest city, [[Toronto]]. East of [[Erie County, New York
column10: Erie County]], the Thruway turns east and passes through the suburbs of several major cities in [[Upstate New York]], generally following the path of the [[Erie Canal]]. It passes south of [[Rochester, New York
column11: Rochester]] and north of [[Syracuse, New York
column12: Syracuse]], which are served by three auxiliary Interstate Highways: [[Interstate 490 (New York)
column15: I-690]] leads to Syracuse.<ref name=\"2009map\">{{cite map
column19: cartography=[[Map Works]]}}</ref>  The speed limit, enforced by the [[New York State Police]], is 65 miles per hour along most of this stretch.<ref name=\"speedlimit\">{{cite web

The Labours of Hercules}}: Approaching exit 54 on I-90 westbound in West Seneca]]

East of Syracuse, the Thruway follows the Erie Canal and, later, the [[Mohawk River]] into the [[Mohawk Valley]] toward [[Utica, New York
the Greek myth: Utica]], where I-90 skirts the northern edge of downtown and meets [[Interstate 790
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: I-790]], a short route leading into the city's center. Farther east, the freeway indirectly serves the canal and riverside cities of [[Little Falls (city), New York
column7: NY 30]]) on its way to [[Schenectady, New York
column9: I-890]] splits from the Thruway and serves as the connection to the city center. It rejoins I-90 in [[Albany County, New York
column10: Albany County]], where I-90 leaves the mainline of the Thruway at exit 24 in [[Albany, New York
column11: Albany]], which is signed for I-87 north and I-90 east. Here, the route designation of the Thruway changes from I-90 east to I-87 south. Traffic intending to continue on I-90 or reach I-87 north must exit the Thruway here. Exit numbers and mile markers for I-90 reset after exiting.<ref name=\"2009map\" />

the Greek myth: Schodack]] section of I-90—the only portion of I-90 in New York that is not part of the Thruway system—begins concurrent with I-87 and heads southeast from Thruway exit 24 to a toll barrier that, for now, marks the end of tolls along the freeway. Now a toll-free highway, I-90 and I-87 continue to exits 1N and 1S, which are for the [[Adirondack Northway]] (I-87) and Fuller Road Alternate (unsigned [[New York State Route 910F
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: NY 910F]]), respectively. Located off exit 1S and Fuller Road Alternate, a spur of the Northway leading to Western Avenue ([[U.S. Route 20 in New York
The Labours of Hercules}}: US 20]]), is the [[Crossgates Mall]] in [[Guilderland, New York
column5: Guilderland]]. I-90 proceeds eastward, meeting Washington Avenue at an interchange connecting to [[University at Albany, SUNY
column6: UAlbany]], a state university, eastbound and Fuller Road ([[County Route 156 (Albany County, New York)
column7: County Route 156]] or CR 156) westbound.<ref name=\"yahoo\">{{yahoo maps
column9: title=overview map of I-90 from Albany to Berkshire Thruway

The Labours of Hercules}}: 1}} apart in an area bounded by Washington and Central ([[New York State Route 5
column5: NY 5]]) avenues, lead to the [[W. Averell Harriman State Office Building Campus]] and the New York State Police Academy (exit 3) and to the Crosstown Arterial ([[New York State Route 85
column6: NY 85]] at exit 4). I-90 subsequently crosses over NY 5 and passes north of [[Westgate Plaza (Albany, New York)
column7: Westgate Plaza]] as it connects to Everett Road ([[County Route 155 (Albany County, New York)
column8: CR 155]]). The freeway continues along the northern edge of Albany to exit 5A,<ref name=\"yahoo\" /> a large [[trumpet interchange]] originally built to serve [[Interstate 687
column13: publisher=New York State Department of Transportation
column14: accessdate=June 11, 2010}}</ref> After that project was cancelled, it was repurposed as an exit for Corporate Woods Boulevard. East of exit 5A, I-90 passes by slightly more residential areas ahead of a [[stack interchange]] with [[U.S. Route 9 in New York
column18: 1}} north of downtown Albany. Albany Memorial Hospital is located just north of the exit on US 9.<ref name=\"yahoo\" />

[[File:I-90 east at US 9 in Albany NY.jpg
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: The stack interchange between I-90 and US 9 in Albany as seen from I-90 eastbound]]

Not far to the east of US 9 is a second stack interchange, connecting I-90 to [[Interstate 787
the Greek myth: I-787]] in the industrial northeasternmost section of the city of Albany. At this point, I-90 turns to the southeast and follows the [[Patroon Island Bridge]] over the [[Hudson River]] and into [[Rensselaer County, New York
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Rensselaer County]]. Across the river, I-90 becomes the Rensselaer County Veterans Memorial Highway and passes through much less developed areas. In its first {{convert
column6: 1}} in the county, the freeway meets Washington Avenue at the northern edge of the city of [[Rensselaer, New York
column7: Rensselaer]] and the west end of [[New York State Route 43
column8: NY 43]] in the town of [[North Greenbush, New York
column9: North Greenbush]], southwest of [[U.S. Route 4 in New York
column11: Defreestville]]. South of NY 43, I-90 and US 4 follow parallel routings into [[East Greenbush, New York
column12: East Greenbush]], where I-90 directly connects to US 4 at exit 9.<ref name=\"yahoo\" />

I-90 heads southeastward across an undeveloped, forested section of the county, crossing over [[New York State Route 151
the Greek myth: NY 151]] and entering the town of Schodack, where it meets Miller Road, a connector between I-90 and the concurrent routes of US 9 and [[U.S. Route 20 in New York
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: US 20]]. The freeway and the overlapping U.S. Routes follow similar routings to [[Schodack Center, New York
The Labours of Hercules}}: Schodack Center]], at which point I-90 finally connects to US 9 and US 20 at exits 11E and 11W. I-90 heads due south from this point, passing over [[New York State Route 150
column5: NY 150]] and paralleling US 9, which splits from US 20 at Schodack Center. The routes cross paths again at exit 12 just north of where I-90 rejoins the Thruway system at a toll barrier preceding exit B1 of the [[Berkshire Connector]].<ref name=\"yahoo\" />

I-90 heads southeast on the Connector, meeting the north end of the [[Taconic State Parkway]] in the [[Columbia County, New York
the Greek myth: Columbia County]] town of [[Chatham (town), New York
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Chatham]] at exit B2 and [[New York State Route 22
The Labours of Hercules}}: NY 22]] at exit B3 in the town of [[Canaan, New York
column8: 1}} from the [[Massachusetts]] state line. The Berkshire Connector ends at the state line; however, I-90 continues southeast into Massachusetts as the [[Massachusetts Turnpike]].<ref name=\"2009map\" />

[[File:I-90 - Thruway split w of Albany NY.jpg
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Overhead signage for exit 24 in Albany, where I-90 leaves the Thruway mainline to serve downtown Albany.]]

The Labours of Hercules}}: The Berkshire Connector (I-90) near exit B2 in Chatham]]

The east–west corridor I-90 follows across New York has always been major, followed by the [[Genesee Trail]] (1790s), [[Erie Canal]] (1825), [[New York Central Railroad]] (1853), and later the [[Yellowstone Trail]] (1912), which became [[U.S. Route 20 in New York
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: NY 5]]. It was planned as part of a nationwide [[toll road]] system as early as 1938.<ref>{{cite map
column6: Location of Routes Selected for Study]]
column7: year=1938}}</ref> Exactly which cities would be served changed over the years, but it was the state of New York that made the decision in 1942, when they passed a law for the construction of a [[New York City]]–[[Albany, New York
column9: Buffalo]]–[[Pennsylvania]] \"thruway\". This highway, passing [[Utica, New York
column12: Rochester]] on its path between Albany and Buffalo, would provide construction jobs in the [[post-World War II]] period.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=sxNLAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Statement+by+Assemblyman+Moffat+and+Senator+Hampton+Relative+to+the+Establishment+of+a+State+Thruway+System%2C+March+13%2C+1942&pgis=1#search Statement by Assemblyman Moffat and Senator Hampton Relative to the Establishment of a State Thruway System, March 13, 1942], New York Legislative Document, 1942, v. 15 no. 80–82, p. 153<!--this citation could use better details--></ref> The [[Berkshire Thruway]], a branch east from near Albany to [[Massachusetts]], was authorized in 1944, completing the east–west route across the state.<ref name=\"thru-hist4\">{{cite book
column18: chapter=The New York State Thruway: The Beginning
column21: url-status=dead }}</ref> However, construction, which began in 1946, proceeded very slowly, with only one four-mile (6 km) portion open by 1950, when a law created the [[New York State Thruway Authority]] (NYSTA) to operate the route as a [[toll road]]. Construction then progressed much more rapidly, especially after 1954, when the authority was allowed to issue [[Bond (finance)
column22: bonds]] not backed by the state (thus having higher [[interest rate]]s).<ref>{{cite book
column25: title=The American Highway: The History and Culture of Roads in the United States
column29: pages=141–142}}</ref> The roadway was completed between Buffalo and Albany in 1954,<ref>{{cite news
column30: title=More of Thruway Opened by Dewey
column35: page=31}}</ref> to New York City in 1956,<ref>{{cite news
column42: title=The Thruway Becomes the Longest Toll Road
column45: page=159}}</ref> and to Massachusetts in 1959.<ref>{{cite news

In the meantime, the [[National Interstate and Defense Highways Act]] was enacted in 1956, promising a toll-free network of [[Interstate Highway]]s throughout the nation. The [[Bureau of Public Roads]] (BPR) commissioner soon announced that the toll road met all federal [[Interstate Highway standards]],<ref>{{cite news
column7: page=39}}</ref> and on August 14, 1957, most of the mainline of the Thruway was incorporated into the system as part of Interstates [[Interstate 87 (New York)
column8: 87]] and 90. Most of the connecting [[Massachusetts Turnpike]] was also included, but a more northerly alignment, avoiding the Berkshire Thruway, was proposed by the states of New York and Massachusetts for I-90 through Albany past [[Pittsfield, MA
column9: Pittsfield]] to [[East Lee, Massachusetts]].<ref name=\"1957map\">{{cite map
column10: publisher=[[American Association of State Highway Officials]]
column12: Official route numbering for the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways]]
column20: title=Traffic Engineering for I90}}</ref> This alignment would be about 30% shorter than the all-toll alignment, and would provide relief to the four-lane [[Castleton Bridge]] on the Berkshire Thruway, which had been built narrower than the rest of the system because of the planned parallel alternate.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?num=100&id=SB8TAAAAIAAJ&dq=relocated+route+20+albany&q=%22The+structure+for+the+toll+route+is+the+only&pgis=1#search Highway Cost Estimates: Hearings before a Subcommittee of the Committee on Public Works], 1958, p. 173</ref><!--this needs more about the piece west of I-787, which is on the 1955 plan--> The BPR objected to the duplication, which would cost over $90 million, and refused to approve this alignment.<ref>[[U.S. Congress]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=H70uAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22bureau+of+public+roads%22+interstate+toll+berkshire&q=berkshire&pgis=1#search Miscellaneous Highway Legislation], 1961, p. 112</ref> The eventual route ran southeast from Albany to the Berkshire Thruway at the [[Nassau (village), New York
column21: Nassau]] interchange, providing Albany with an alternate route and additional bridge, but not offering any savings in distance, and creating a \"toll trap\" for drivers accessing the [[Taconic State Parkway]] from Albany.<ref>{{cite news
column22: title=Rockefeller Urged to Veto Road Link

Construction on the route of I-90 through Albany began {{circa
the Greek myth: 1963}}, with both ends at existing Thruway interchanges: exit 24, which crossed the [[Adirondack Northway]] (I-87) at a [[cloverleaf interchange]] and connected to Washington Avenue in western Albany, and exit B1, which connected to [[U.S. Route 9 in New York
column13: edition=1963}}</ref> Work on the freeway began at the Northway and progressed southeasterly to the Berkshire Connector in Rensselaer County. The portion between the Northway and Everett Road was opened to traffic in the mid-1960s<ref>{{cite map
column22: cartography=General Drafting}}</ref> while the piece extending from Everett Road to [[U.S. Route 4 in New York
column24: Rensselaer]] was completed in the early 1970s.<ref>{{cite map
column26: publisher=[[State of New York Department of Commerce]]
column29: title=New York and New Jersey Tourgide<!--sic--> Map
column33: edition=1972}}</ref> The last section of the highway was completed to US 9 and [[U.S. Route 20 in New York
column43: title=New York and New Jersey Tourgide<!--sic--> Map
column51: cartography=General Drafting}}</ref> The Northway cloverleaf was rebuilt in the late 1980s.<ref>{{cite journal
column54: work=[[National Bridge Inventory]]

In 1999, the [[New York State Department of Transportation]], the [[Federal Highway Administration]] and NYSTA discussed redesignating the [[Berkshire Connector]] as I-90 and redesignating the non-toll part of I-90 from Thruway exit 24 to exit B1 on the Connector as [[Interstate 88 (east)
the Greek myth: I-88]]. The section of the Thruway between exits 25 and 24 would then be [[concurrency (road)
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: co-designated]] as both I-90 and I-88. This was never implemented.<ref>{{cite web
column8: publisher=Capital District Transportation Committee and New York State Department of Transportation

The mileposts below for the non-thruway section follow actual signage, where mile 0.00 is located just east of the toll booths for Exit 24 of the Thruway.<ref>{{cite web

column12: Syracuse]], which are served by three auxiliary Interstate Highways: [[Interstate 490 (New York)
column15: I-690]] leads to Syracuse.<ref name=\"2009map\">{{cite map
column19: cartography=[[Map Works]]}}</ref>  The speed limit, enforced by the [[New York State Police]], is 65 miles per hour along most of this stretch.<ref name=\"speedlimit\">{{cite web

The Labours of Hercules}}: Approaching exit 54 on I-90 westbound in West Seneca]]

East of Syracuse, the Thruway follows the Erie Canal and, later, the [[Mohawk River]] into the [[Mohawk Valley]] toward [[Utica, New York
the Greek myth: Utica]], where I-90 skirts the northern edge of downtown and meets [[Interstate 790
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: I-790]], a short route leading into the city's center. Farther east, the freeway indirectly serves the canal and riverside cities of [[Little Falls (city), New York
column7: NY 30]]) on its way to [[Schenectady, New York
column9: I-890]] splits from the Thruway and serves as the connection to the city center. It rejoins I-90 in [[Albany County, New York
column10: Albany County]], where I-90 leaves the mainline of the Thruway at exit 24 in [[Albany, New York
column11: Albany]], which is signed for I-87 north and I-90 east. Here, the route designation of the Thruway changes from I-90 east to I-87 south. Traffic intending to continue on I-90 or reach I-87 north must exit the Thruway here. Exit numbers and mile markers for I-90 reset after exiting.<ref name=\"2009map\" />

the Greek myth: Schodack]] section of I-90—the only portion of I-90 in New York that is not part of the Thruway system—begins concurrent with I-87 and heads southeast from Thruway exit 24 to a toll barrier that, for now, marks the end of tolls along the freeway. Now a toll-free highway, I-90 and I-87 continue to exits 1N and 1S, which are for the [[Adirondack Northway]] (I-87) and Fuller Road Alternate (unsigned [[New York State Route 910F
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: NY 910F]]), respectively. Located off exit 1S and Fuller Road Alternate, a spur of the Northway leading to Western Avenue ([[U.S. Route 20 in New York
The Labours of Hercules}}: US 20]]), is the [[Crossgates Mall]] in [[Guilderland, New York
column5: Guilderland]]. I-90 proceeds eastward, meeting Washington Avenue at an interchange connecting to [[University at Albany, SUNY
column6: UAlbany]], a state university, eastbound and Fuller Road ([[County Route 156 (Albany County, New York)
column7: County Route 156]] or CR 156) westbound.<ref name=\"yahoo\">{{yahoo maps
column9: title=overview map of I-90 from Albany to Berkshire Thruway

The Labours of Hercules}}: 1}} apart in an area bounded by Washington and Central ([[New York State Route 5
column5: NY 5]]) avenues, lead to the [[W. Averell Harriman State Office Building Campus]] and the New York State Police Academy (exit 3) and to the Crosstown Arterial ([[New York State Route 85
column6: NY 85]] at exit 4). I-90 subsequently crosses over NY 5 and passes north of [[Westgate Plaza (Albany, New York)
column7: Westgate Plaza]] as it connects to Everett Road ([[County Route 155 (Albany County, New York)
column8: CR 155]]). The freeway continues along the northern edge of Albany to exit 5A,<ref name=\"yahoo\" /> a large [[trumpet interchange]] originally built to serve [[Interstate 687
column13: publisher=New York State Department of Transportation
column14: accessdate=June 11, 2010}}</ref> After that project was cancelled, it was repurposed as an exit for Corporate Woods Boulevard. East of exit 5A, I-90 passes by slightly more residential areas ahead of a [[stack interchange]] with [[U.S. Route 9 in New York
column18: 1}} north of downtown Albany. Albany Memorial Hospital is located just north of the exit on US 9.<ref name=\"yahoo\" />

[[File:I-90 east at US 9 in Albany NY.jpg
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: The stack interchange between I-90 and US 9 in Albany as seen from I-90 eastbound]]

Not far to the east of US 9 is a second stack interchange, connecting I-90 to [[Interstate 787
the Greek myth: I-787]] in the industrial northeasternmost section of the city of Albany. At this point, I-90 turns to the southeast and follows the [[Patroon Island Bridge]] over the [[Hudson River]] and into [[Rensselaer County, New York
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Rensselaer County]]. Across the river, I-90 becomes the Rensselaer County Veterans Memorial Highway and passes through much less developed areas. In its first {{convert
column6: 1}} in the county, the freeway meets Washington Avenue at the northern edge of the city of [[Rensselaer, New York
column7: Rensselaer]] and the west end of [[New York State Route 43
column8: NY 43]] in the town of [[North Greenbush, New York
column9: North Greenbush]], southwest of [[U.S. Route 4 in New York
column11: Defreestville]]. South of NY 43, I-90 and US 4 follow parallel routings into [[East Greenbush, New York
column12: East Greenbush]], where I-90 directly connects to US 4 at exit 9.<ref name=\"yahoo\" />

I-90 heads southeastward across an undeveloped, forested section of the county, crossing over [[New York State Route 151
the Greek myth: NY 151]] and entering the town of Schodack, where it meets Miller Road, a connector between I-90 and the concurrent routes of US 9 and [[U.S. Route 20 in New York
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: US 20]]. The freeway and the overlapping U.S. Routes follow similar routings to [[Schodack Center, New York
The Labours of Hercules}}: Schodack Center]], at which point I-90 finally connects to US 9 and US 20 at exits 11E and 11W. I-90 heads due south from this point, passing over [[New York State Route 150
column5: NY 150]] and paralleling US 9, which splits from US 20 at Schodack Center. The routes cross paths again at exit 12 just north of where I-90 rejoins the Thruway system at a toll barrier preceding exit B1 of the [[Berkshire Connector]].<ref name=\"yahoo\" />

I-90 heads southeast on the Connector, meeting the north end of the [[Taconic State Parkway]] in the [[Columbia County, New York
the Greek myth: Columbia County]] town of [[Chatham (town), New York
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Chatham]] at exit B2 and [[New York State Route 22
The Labours of Hercules}}: NY 22]] at exit B3 in the town of [[Canaan, New York
column8: 1}} from the [[Massachusetts]] state line. The Berkshire Connector ends at the state line; however, I-90 continues southeast into Massachusetts as the [[Massachusetts Turnpike]].<ref name=\"2009map\" />

[[File:I-90 - Thruway split w of Albany NY.jpg
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Overhead signage for exit 24 in Albany, where I-90 leaves the Thruway mainline to serve downtown Albany.]]

The Labours of Hercules}}: The Berkshire Connector (I-90) near exit B2 in Chatham]]

The east–west corridor I-90 follows across New York has always been major, followed by the [[Genesee Trail]] (1790s), [[Erie Canal]] (1825), [[New York Central Railroad]] (1853), and later the [[Yellowstone Trail]] (1912), which became [[U.S. Route 20 in New York
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: NY 5]]. It was planned as part of a nationwide [[toll road]] system as early as 1938.<ref>{{cite map
column6: Location of Routes Selected for Study]]
column7: year=1938}}</ref> Exactly which cities would be served changed over the years, but it was the state of New York that made the decision in 1942, when they passed a law for the construction of a [[New York City]]–[[Albany, New York
column9: Buffalo]]–[[Pennsylvania]] \"thruway\". This highway, passing [[Utica, New York
column12: Rochester]] on its path between Albany and Buffalo, would provide construction jobs in the [[post-World War II]] period.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=sxNLAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Statement+by+Assemblyman+Moffat+and+Senator+Hampton+Relative+to+the+Establishment+of+a+State+Thruway+System%2C+March+13%2C+1942&pgis=1#search Statement by Assemblyman Moffat and Senator Hampton Relative to the Establishment of a State Thruway System, March 13, 1942], New York Legislative Document, 1942, v. 15 no. 80–82, p. 153<!--this citation could use better details--></ref> The [[Berkshire Thruway]], a branch east from near Albany to [[Massachusetts]], was authorized in 1944, completing the east–west route across the state.<ref name=\"thru-hist4\">{{cite book
column18: chapter=The New York State Thruway: The Beginning
column21: url-status=dead }}</ref> However, construction, which began in 1946, proceeded very slowly, with only one four-mile (6 km) portion open by 1950, when a law created the [[New York State Thruway Authority]] (NYSTA) to operate the route as a [[toll road]]. Construction then progressed much more rapidly, especially after 1954, when the authority was allowed to issue [[Bond (finance)
column22: bonds]] not backed by the state (thus having higher [[interest rate]]s).<ref>{{cite book
column25: title=The American Highway: The History and Culture of Roads in the United States
column29: pages=141–142}}</ref> The roadway was completed between Buffalo and Albany in 1954,<ref>{{cite news
column30: title=More of Thruway Opened by Dewey
column35: page=31}}</ref> to New York City in 1956,<ref>{{cite news
column42: title=The Thruway Becomes the Longest Toll Road
column45: page=159}}</ref> and to Massachusetts in 1959.<ref>{{cite news

In the meantime, the [[National Interstate and Defense Highways Act]] was enacted in 1956, promising a toll-free network of [[Interstate Highway]]s throughout the nation. The [[Bureau of Public Roads]] (BPR) commissioner soon announced that the toll road met all federal [[Interstate Highway standards]],<ref>{{cite news
column7: page=39}}</ref> and on August 14, 1957, most of the mainline of the Thruway was incorporated into the system as part of Interstates [[Interstate 87 (New York)
column8: 87]] and 90. Most of the connecting [[Massachusetts Turnpike]] was also included, but a more northerly alignment, avoiding the Berkshire Thruway, was proposed by the states of New York and Massachusetts for I-90 through Albany past [[Pittsfield, MA
column9: Pittsfield]] to [[East Lee, Massachusetts]].<ref name=\"1957map\">{{cite map
column10: publisher=[[American Association of State Highway Officials]]
column12: Official route numbering for the National System of Interstate and Defense Highways]]
column20: title=Traffic Engineering for I90}}</ref> This alignment would be about 30% shorter than the all-toll alignment, and would provide relief to the four-lane [[Castleton Bridge]] on the Berkshire Thruway, which had been built narrower than the rest of the system because of the planned parallel alternate.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?num=100&id=SB8TAAAAIAAJ&dq=relocated+route+20+albany&q=%22The+structure+for+the+toll+route+is+the+only&pgis=1#search Highway Cost Estimates: Hearings before a Subcommittee of the Committee on Public Works], 1958, p. 173</ref><!--this needs more about the piece west of I-787, which is on the 1955 plan--> The BPR objected to the duplication, which would cost over $90 million, and refused to approve this alignment.<ref>[[U.S. Congress]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=H70uAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22bureau+of+public+roads%22+interstate+toll+berkshire&q=berkshire&pgis=1#search Miscellaneous Highway Legislation], 1961, p. 112</ref> The eventual route ran southeast from Albany to the Berkshire Thruway at the [[Nassau (village), New York
column21: Nassau]] interchange, providing Albany with an alternate route and additional bridge, but not offering any savings in distance, and creating a \"toll trap\" for drivers accessing the [[Taconic State Parkway]] from Albany.<ref>{{cite news
column22: title=Rockefeller Urged to Veto Road Link

Construction on the route of I-90 through Albany began {{circa
the Greek myth: 1963}}, with both ends at existing Thruway interchanges: exit 24, which crossed the [[Adirondack Northway]] (I-87) at a [[cloverleaf interchange]] and connected to Washington Avenue in western Albany, and exit B1, which connected to [[U.S. Route 9 in New York
column13: edition=1963}}</ref> Work on the freeway began at the Northway and progressed southeasterly to the Berkshire Connector in Rensselaer County. The portion between the Northway and Everett Road was opened to traffic in the mid-1960s<ref>{{cite map
column22: cartography=General Drafting}}</ref> while the piece extending from Everett Road to [[U.S. Route 4 in New York
column24: Rensselaer]] was completed in the early 1970s.<ref>{{cite map
column26: publisher=[[State of New York Department of Commerce]]
column29: title=New York and New Jersey Tourgide<!--sic--> Map
column33: edition=1972}}</ref> The last section of the highway was completed to US 9 and [[U.S. Route 20 in New York
column43: title=New York and New Jersey Tourgide<!--sic--> Map
column51: cartography=General Drafting}}</ref> The Northway cloverleaf was rebuilt in the late 1980s.<ref>{{cite journal
column54: work=[[National Bridge Inventory]]

In 1999, the [[New York State Department of Transportation]], the [[Federal Highway Administration]] and NYSTA discussed redesignating the [[Berkshire Connector]] as I-90 and redesignating the non-toll part of I-90 from Thruway exit 24 to exit B1 on the Connector as [[Interstate 88 (east)
the Greek myth: I-88]]. The section of the Thruway between exits 25 and 24 would then be [[concurrency (road)
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: co-designated]] as both I-90 and I-88. This was never implemented.<ref>{{cite web
column8: publisher=Capital District Transportation Committee and New York State Department of Transportation

The mileposts below for the non-thruway section follow actual signage, where mile 0.00 is located just east of the toll booths for Exit 24 of the Thruway.<ref>{{cite web

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Thruway Authority Announces Start of Bridge Removal Project in the Town of Hamburg
column10: title=How the Thruway Authority Will Change Exit 57 in Hamburg
