caption= The [[Black Standard]] of the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].

The Labours of Hercules}}: title=Islamic State video promotes Somali arm, incites attacks during holidays

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Islamic State}} [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Yemen Province
column5: Flag of Edward England.svg}} [[Piracy off the coast of Somalia
column8: title=CNN Exclusive: Somali pirate kings are under investigation for helping ISIS and al-Shabaab

The '''Islamic State in Somalia''' (short: '''ISS''') or '''Abnaa ul-Calipha''' is an [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]-affiliated group that primarily operates in the mountainous areas of [[Puntland]], though has also claimed responsibility for several terrorist attacks throughout the rest of [[Somalia]]. Led by Sheikh [[Abdul Qadir Mumin]], the group is estimated to have up to 300 active fighters. Since its formation, ISS probably managed to take control of a small, sparsely populated territory in northern Somalia's mountainous hinterland, though it was not acknowledged as [[ISIL territorial claims
the Greek myth: official province]] (\"Wilayat\") by ISIL's central leadership until December 2017. Since then, it has sometimes been called '''Somalia Province''' (\"Wilayat al Somal\") by pro-ISIL media. ISS is also the declared enemy of [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: al-Shabaab]], which considers the Islamic State a significant threat to its own predominance among Jihadist factions in Somalia.

The origins of the Islamic State in Somalia trace back to 2012, when [[Abdul Qadir Mumin]] was sent by the al-Shabaab leadership to its remote outpost in Puntland, far from the insurgent group's primary areas of operation in southern Somalia. As cleric with little military experience, Mumin's role in Puntland was originally to attract recruits for the numerical small and militarily weak local al-Shabaab group, which was led by [[Mohamed Said Atom]] at the time. In course of the [[Galgala campaign]] in 2014, however, Atom defected to the government, and Mumin was forced to take control of the Puntland group. Isolated in the remote north and feeling increasingly distanced from al-Shabaab, Mumin began to consider himself more and more independent.{{sfnp
Meanwhile, the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant had launched a propaganda campaign to convince al-Shabaab to join to them, which was \"angrily refused\" by al-Shabaab's central leadership.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=30}} Despite this, several groups of al-Shabaab members found ISIL's ideology attractive or saw this new Jihadist organization as a way to challenge al-Shabaab's leadership at the time. Thus, several small pro-ISIL groups emerged in southern Somalia. This was however not tolerated by the Somali organization, which released statements condemning dissenters{{efn
column6: Al-Shabaab radio stations for example declared in November 2015: \"If anyone says he belongs to another Islamic movement [other than that of al-Qa'ida], kill him on the spot ... we will cut the throat of anyone ... if they undermine unity.\" Al-Shabaab spokesman Ali Mahmud Rage similarly claimed that dissenters in the organization were \"infidels\" who would be \"burnt in hell\".{{sfnp
column10: p=28}} }} and ordered its internal security service Amniyat to arrest or kill pro-ISIL elements such as Hussein Abdi Gedi's faction in [[Middle Juba]].{{sfnp

Mumin, however, long dissatisfied with his situation, pledged ''[[bay'ah]]'' to [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]] and the Islamic State in October 2015. This caused a violent split within Puntland's al-Shabaab, as only 20 of the 300 local Islamist fighters joined Mumin,{{sfnp
column6: title=Islamic State in Somalia claims capture of port town
column10: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> while the al-Shabaab loyalists attempted to kill these defectors. Mumin's small group proceeded to form ''Abnaa ul-Calipha'', better known as ''Islamic State in Somalia'', and to evade their erstwhile comrades, while recruiting new members for their cause.<ref name=\"vow\">{{cite web
column12: title=Somali Officials Vow to Retake Puntland Town
column16: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> Al-Baghdadi and the ISIL leadership did not acknowledge Mumin's bay'ah, instead choosing to wait and see how the Islamic State in Somalia fared.{{sfnp
column19: p=30}} While Mumin's group in the north thus managed to survive, the situation of pro-ISIL forces in southern Somalia consequently became even more precarious. In two notable incidents in November and December 2015, al-Shabaab attacked and destroyed two of the most important southern ISIL cells, namely the ones of Bashir Abu Numan and Mohammad Makkawi Ibrahim. Pro-government forces such as the [[Somali Armed Forces]] and [[Ahlu Sunna Waljama'a]] also claimed to have targeted southern ISIL groups. As result, ISIL forces in southern Somialia remained very weak,{{sfnp
column23: pp=28, 29}} and those that survived appear to have accepted Mumin's authority over time, formally becoming part of ISS.{{sfnp
column27: pp=27, 28}} As result, the \"disparate clump of pro-Islamic State cells\" in Somalia transformed into an \"organized group\".{{sfnp

=== Rise in power and Qandala campaign ===

The Labours of Hercules}}: A variant of the Islamic State in Somalia's usual [[Black Standard
column5: black flag]], which is also sometimes used by the group.<ref name=\"camp\">{{cite web
column7: title=Islamic State highlights ‘first camp of the Caliphate in Somalia’

In March 2016, an ISS cell in southern Puntland was pursued by al-Shabaab fighters into [[Mudug]]; the pursuers were however attacked and completely defeated by the [[Puntland Dervish Force]] and [[Military of Galmudug
the Greek myth: Galmudug soldiers]], thus unintentionally allowing the Islamic State militants to escape into safety.<ref name=\"puntland state\">{{cite web
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=The Islamic State Threat in Somalia’s Puntland State
column9: accessdate=13 July 2017}}</ref> From this point onwards, ISS and al-Shabaab temporarily ceased fighting each other with the exception of some isolated incidents.{{sfnp
column12: p=30}} Over the following months Mumin's followers built up their strength, and by April 2016 they had set up a temporary training camp named after Bashir Abu Numan, the ISIL follower mentioned above who had been killed by al-Shabaab in November 2015.<ref name=\"camp\" />{{sfnp
column16: p=29}} In one of the group's propaganda videos, Mumin blessed the makeshift base as the \"first camp of the Caliphate in Somalia\". On 25 April, ISS also carried out its first attack on government forces, when one of its fighters detonated an [[Improvised explosive device
column17: IED]] against an [[African Union Mission to Somalia
column18: AMISOM]] vehicle in [[Mogadishu]].<ref name=\"camp\" /> By August 2016, Mumin's cell still remained very small, probably under 100 militants, and was not yet very active. According to the [[United States Department of State]], however, ISS began to expand in size by abducting and indoctrinating boys between 10 and 15 and employing them as [[Military use of children
column21: title=US adds Islamic State commander in Somalia to list of global terrorists

By October 2016, ISS had claimed less than one dozen attacks overall since its foundation, showing that the group was still relatively weak. Nevertheless, the fact that many of these strikes had taken place in Mogadishu, indicated that ISS had become able to operate throughout wider Somalia, not just in its core regions in Puntland.<ref name=\"port town\" /> Experts also estimated that Mumin's cell had significantly grown to up to 300 fighters. On 26 October, the group eventually launched their first major operation by [[Qandala campaign
the Greek myth: targeting]] the major port town of [[Qandala]]. The town had both symbolic as well as strategic significance, as it could allow ISS to bolster their local support and receive more supplies from Yemen. The Islamic State fighters managed to overrun the town, meeting little resistance, and thereafter controlled it largely unchallenged until 3 December. On that day, the [[Puntland Security Force]] launched a counter-offensive, and after sporadic fighting for four days, retook Qandala on 7 December 2016.<ref name=\"vow\" /><ref name=\"retake\">{{cite web
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=Forces Retake Somali Town Held by Pro-Islamic State Fighters
column11: p=30}} Mumin's men were forced to retreat to El Ladid, a village 30 kilometers south of Qandala, where government forces once again attacked and scattered them on 18 December.<ref name=\"base\">{{cite web
column13: title=Regional Somali Forces 'Destroy' Islamic State Base
column17: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> Overall, ISS suffered numerous casualties during the Qandala campaign,<ref name=\"retake\" /> but had scored a symbolic victory nonetheless, having captured and held a major town for more than a month.{{sfnp
column20: p=30}} Having established a new headquarters in the al-Mishkat Mountains, ISS subsequently managed to attract new recruits, mostly children and orphans, though also some new defectors from al-Shabaab.<ref name=\"growing threat\">{{cite web
column22: title=The growing threat of Islamic State in Somalia
column26: accessdate=13 July 2017}}</ref> It also became generally more active.{{sfnp

=== Expanded terrorist attacks and announcement of Wilayat al Somal ===

The Labours of Hercules}}: ISS launched an unsuccessful attack on the Village Hotel in [[Bosaso]] in February 2017 ]]

The Qandala campaign resulted in the Puntland government as well as the [[African Union]] taking ISS more seriously, with both taking more steps to counter ISS' growing strength.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=30}} In addition, ISS began to cooperate with al-Shabaab to a limited degree during the subsequent months.{{sfnp
column7: p=33}} On 8 February 2017, ISS launched its next major attack in Puntland, with several militants of the group attacking the Village Hotel in [[Bosaso]]. A fierce shootout ensued, with the hotel's guards eventually repelling the attackers. At least four guards and two ISS fighters died during the fighting.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Islamic State claims hotel attack in northern Somalia
column13: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> On 28 March 2017, ISS [[List of terrorist incidents in March 2017
column14: ambushed]] a convoy of Puntland soldiers near Qandala. The attackers retreated into the hills after inflicting two casualties on the government forces.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=One soldier killed, one wounded by roadside bomb in Somalia's Puntland
column21: accessdate=31 March 2017}}</ref> On 16 April, the group occupied Dasan village near Qandala, though abandoned it again after a few hours.<ref name=\"growing threat\" /> ISS was also blamed for a roadside bomb in [[Galgala]] on 23 April that killed 8 soldiers and injured 3 others.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Roadside bomb in Somalia kills 8 soldiers
column26: accessdate=25 April 2017}}</ref> On 23 May 2017, ISS carried out a suicide bombing, which was possibly the group's very first [[suicide attack]]. When the ISS suicide bomber tried to close in on the Juba Hotel in Bosaso, he was stopped at a military checkpoint, causing him to detonate his explosives, killing five and wounding twelve.<ref>{{cite web
column28: title=Islamic State claims suicide bombing in Somalia
column34: title=Suicide bomber kills five in Somalia's northern Puntland region

In June 2017, a Puntland military official claimed that ISS had been reduced to around 70 active fighters, and sustained itself by stealing food and livestock from local communities.<ref name=\"surrender\">{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Somalia: ISIS fighter surrenders to Puntland authorities
column7: accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> Regional expert [[Matthew Bryden]], on the other side, said that ISS still had up to 300 fighters and had become entrenched in the eastern Galaga mountains, where it had gained the support of some local communities which felt ignored by the government.<ref name=\"Vow Revenge\">{{cite web
column9: title=Somali Officials Condemn Attacks, Vow Revenge
column13: accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref> Observers also noted that ISS had significantly increased their output of propaganda material in an attempt to sway disenfranchised locals<ref name=\"growing threat\" /> and international jihadists to their side.<ref name=\"British jihadi\">{{cite web
column15: title=British jihadi bids to be leader of Islamic State
column19: accessdate=7 August 2017}}</ref> By late 2017, the [[United Nations]] estimated that Mumin's group was about 200 fighters strong.<ref name=\"footprint\">{{cite web
column21: title=Islamic State's footprint spreading in northern Somalia: U.N.

In November 2017, the [[United States]] launched their first airstrikes on ISS, reportedly killing several members of the group<ref>{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=US launches first airstrikes against ISIS in Somalia
column10: title=US targets Islamic State in northeastern Somalia
column15: accessdate=30 December 2017}}</ref> in Buqo Valley, east of Bosaso. They failed to kill Mumin, however, who had been the main target of the bombings.<ref name=\"Survives Strike\">{{cite web
column17: title=Somali Pro-IS Group Chief Survives US Strike, Says Regional Leader
column21: accessdate=10 September 2018 }}</ref> Observers noted that these airstrikes indicated that the US military had come to see ISS as considerable threat to the stability of the region.<ref name=\"footprint\"/> On 25 December, ISIL released an [[Persecution of Christians
column22: anti-Christian]] propaganda video under the name \"Hunt Them Down, O Monotheists\", in which the Islamic State in Somalia was called Wilayat al Somal (Somalia Province), thus seemingly elevating the group to an official province of the proclaimed worldwide caliphate of ISIL.<ref name=\"holidays\"/> Since then, however, the new name has not been consistently applied to the group by pro-ISIL media.{{sfnp

[[File:Puntland Police on Alert as Somalia Terror Threat Moves North.webm
The Labours of Hercules}}: March 2018 ''[[Voice of America]]'' report about the activities of ISS and [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)

Meanwhile, ISS started to launch assassination attempts in the region around Mogadishu from November 2017, with the town [[Afgooye]] most affected.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=16}} From then on, the group greatly increased its rate of attacks on government targets.{{sfnp
column7: p=30}} By May 2018, ISS had reportedly carried out eleven attacks and killed 23 people who had allegedly worked for the government, such as intelligence agents, soldiers, officials, and policemen. In response to these assaults, the [[National Intelligence and Security Agency]] started to arrest suspected ISS members in and around Mogadishu.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Analysis: Islamic State ramps up attack claims in Somalia
column15: title=Somali intelligence agency arrests two Islamic State members in Mogadishu
column19: accessdate=14 June 2018 }}</ref> ISS also abducted nine people in the region around Qandala in January 2018, including some off-duty soldiers. The militia later tortured and decapitated at least three of them, leaving them along a road to be found by passersby.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Decapitated bodies found in Somalia days after 'Islamic State' abductions
column25: accessdate=14 June 2018 }}</ref> At the end of 2018, ISS claimed to have carried out 66 attacks, more than in 2016 and 2017 combined.{{sfnp

column5: quote=As we record these crimes, we do not do so as a complaint or out of weakness, but to teach people, especially our people in Somalia, what the al Qaeda branch in Somalia has done, because the response from the Islamic State is coming.
column6: source=—Islamic State in Somalia warning to [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)

The group also grew more sophisticated and further expanded its presence throughout Somalia. It had begun to collect taxes (essentially [[Protection racket
the Greek myth: protection money]]) on businesses in Bosaso by August 2018, greatly increasing its revenue.{{sfnp
column5: p=30}} At some point in 2018, ISS managed to convince a significant number of al-Shabaab militants to defect, resulting in the formation of an Islamic State cell in [[Beledweyne]].{{sfnp
column8: pp=30–31}} As result of its increasing activity in central and southern Somalia, the rivalry between ISS and al-Shabaab reignited in full, with several clashes occurring between the groups. In October 2018, al-Shabaab probably executed ISS depuy Mahad Maalin in Mogadishu,{{sfnp
column11: p=31}} while Islamic State forces ambushed an al-Shabaab group near B'ir Mirali southwest of Qandala, reportedly killing 14 rival militants.{{sfnp
column14: p=32}} The growing violence between the two jihadist rebel factions resulted in al-Shabaab central command releasing a speech as well as an 18-page treatise on 20 December 2018. In these works, the Islamic State  was sharply rebuked as corrupt, apostate, and seditionist force, while al-Shabaab authorized its loyalists to destroy ISS elements as \"disease in the Jihad\". This amounted to an official [[declaration of war]].{{sfnp

In the next months, the two factions greatly increased their attacks against each other: They clashed near [[El Adde]] in December 2018, and at numerous locations in Puntland between January and March 2019. ISS reportedly suffered one major setback during these clashes when it lost one of its main bases in the Dasaan area to al-Shabaab.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=32}} Regardless, neither organizations appears to have suffered to a tangible degree from this inter-rebel fighting, and both have continued to strike government targets.{{sfnp
column7: p=33}} The United States Air Force carried out an airstrike against ISS on 14 April 2019, killing its deputy Abdihakim Mohamed Ibrahim at Xiriiro, Bari region.<ref name=\"no2\">{{cite web
column9: title=US Confirms Airstrike Kills Deputy Leader of IS Militants in Somalia
column13: access-date=17 August 2019}}</ref> On 12 July 2019, ISS militants clashed with security forces near the Safa hotel in Puntland's capital, Bosaso, the same day as an al-Shabaab attack on a hotel in [[Kismayo]].<ref>{{Cite news
column18: access-date=21 July 2019}}</ref> The United States Air Force bombed an ISS base in the [[Golis Mountains]] on 8 May 2019, reportedly killing 13 militants.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=US airstrike kills 13 Somalia ISIS fighters, AFRICOM says

On 27 October 2019, ISIL Caliph Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was killed in the [[Barisha raid]], whereupon the organisation's central command elected [[Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi]] as new leader. On 4 November, the Islamic State in Somalia officially pledged allegiance to al-Qurashi.{{sfnp
column6: title=US Takes Notice as More Islamic State Branches Back New Leader
column12: title=Somali ISIS affiliate swears allegiance to new leader
column15: access-date=2019-11-04}}</ref> By this time, ISS was regarded as important element in ISIL's international network, but still suffered from an inability to expand due to pressure by  al-Shabaab, the Somali Armed Forces, and the [[United States Armed Forces]]. From late 2019, the group consequently attempted to become more active beyond Somalia's borders, as its forces tried to infiltrate Ethiopia and recruit new forces there.{{sfnp
column18: pp=5–6}} Its operations in Ethiopia were repeatedly crushed by local security forces, and several militants were arrested.{{sfnp
column23: title=Islamic State trains in Somalia's Puntland
column27: accessdate=19 March 2020 }}</ref> ISS had also set up a new training camp, codenamed \"Dawoud al Somali\", probably in northern Puntland.<ref name=\"trains\" />

The Labours of Hercules}}: ISS is primarily active in the eastern Galaga Mountains, which mostly lie in the Bari region of [[Puntland]].]]

The Islamic State in Somalia is led by Abdul Qadir Mumin, whose role for the continued existence of the group has been judged to be extremely important.{{sfnp
column5: p=31}} Described as \"eloquent and persuasive, [...] very savvy and sophisticated\", Mumin is deeply involved in international jihadism and considered to be an extremely dangerous terrorist leader. After reports circulated in June/July 2017 that Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi had been killed, terror expert Candyce Kelshall even speculated that Mumin might be tempted to declare himself the new caliph of ISIL.<ref name=\"British jihadi\" /> Mumin's direct control is however limited to ISS forces in northern Somalia. Though pro-ISIL cells in the southern parts of the country have probably accepted Mumin as their official leader,{{sfnp
column9: pp=27, 28}} the exact relationship between the northern and southern groups of ISS remains unclear. It is possible that the latter only have nominal links to the northern branch or no actual contact at all.{{sfnp
column13: p=28}} In any case, the southern cells remain mostly weak and exist in a precarious state, constantly threatened by al-Shabaab.{{sfnp

Besides Mumin, two other ISS commanders were known: Mahad Maalin served as field commander<ref name=\"retake\"/> and deputy of the group until his death in October 2018.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=30}} He was succeeded as deputy by Abdihakim Mohamed Ibrahim, alias \"Dhoqob\", who was believed to be Mumin's \"right-hand man\". Dhoqob was killed on 14 April 2019, and his death was portrayed by the [[United States Africa Command]] as major blow to ISS.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=US confirms killing No.2 Islamic State leader in Somalia

column5: p=30}} that ISS controls a relatively small territory in Puntland's mountainous hinterland,<ref name=\"Vow Revenge\" /> the group is not known to have attempted to set up something resembling a government at any point of its existence. ISS' current areas are only very sparsely settled or not populated at all,{{sfnp
column9: p=30}} while Qandala's civilian population completely fled during its occupation by the militants.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Last Resident Leaves Somali Town Taken by Islamic State
column15: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> By November 2019, ISS controlled the villages of Dhasaan and Shebaab in Bari region.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Letter dated 1 November 2019 from the Chair of the Security Council Committee pursuant to resolution 751 (1992) concerning Somalia addressed to the President of the Security Council
column19: date=1 November 2019}}</ref> The group is known to use caves as hiding places.<ref name=\"Survives Strike\"/>

The strength of the Islamic State in Somalia fluctuated over time, and is not known with certainty. Mumin's initial cell was estimated at about 20 members, growing to less than 100 by August 2016. At the time of the Qandala campaign, a former [[Puntland Intelligence Agency]] official argued that ISS counted 200 to 300 militants. Following its defeat at Qandala, local observers judged that the group declined to just 70–150 members by June 2017.{{sfnp
column5: p=24}} The Islamic State in Somalia subsequently recruited new fighters to alleviate its manpower shortage, though Somali journalists gave widely different accounts on the success of this recruitment drive. Accordingly, ISS was believed to be between 100 and 300 militants strong by mid-2018.{{sfnp
column9: pp=24–25}} The vast majority of ISS members are Somalis, with only a few [[Mujahideen#Somalia
column10: foreign mujahideen]] fighting for the group, including Sudanese, Yemenis,{{sfnp
column14: p=30}}<ref name=\"footprint\" /> Ethiopians,<ref name=\"holidays\"/> and Egyptians.{{sfnp

The propaganda of ISS is generally extremely inferior compared to its direct rival al-Shabaab. The Islamic State in Somalia initially had no media wing of its own and also has not organized a \"robust informal media presence\".{{sfnp
column5: p=31}} Instead, it mostly relies on the existing propaganda channels of ISIL, such as the [[Amaq News Agency]],{{sfnp
column12: p=31}} the ''Global Front to Support the Islamic State'', and the media arms of other ISIL branches in [[Iraq]], [[Syria]], [[Yemen]], [[Egypt]], and [[Libya]].{{sfnp
column15: p=29}} The propaganda video of December 2017 that declared ISS a province, however, also claimed to have been produced by the \"Media Office of Wilayat al Somal\".<ref name=\"holidays\"/> In late 2019, ISS began releasing propaganda in [[Amharic]], a language widely spoken in Ethiopia, in an attempt to attract new recruits there.{{sfnp

the Greek myth: Piracy off the coast of Somalia}}

In its endeavor to build up its military strength, the Islamic State in Somalia is aided by the fact that Puntland's government has only limited control over its hinterland while its military is overstrechted. Peripheral areas are thus mostly ignored by the security forces and instead run by rebellious and infighting tribal militias. As result, local clans (including Mumin's own, the [[Majeerteen]] Ali Saleban) are aggrieved by their perceived marginalisation by the government and in some cases ready to support ISS. Such dissatisfied elements are the ones from which ISS receives supplies and recruits new members.<ref name=\"puntland state\" /><ref name=\"growing threat\" />{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=30}} There have also been accounts, however, that ISS raids those communities which do not supply it with food and other necessities,<ref name=\"surrender\" /> and to kidnap children in order to indoctrinate and train them as child soldiers.<ref name=\"list global\" /> The group is also known to collect taxes in areas which it controls or at least influences.{{sfnp

The group is also directly supported by the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Yemen Province]], which is known to have sent experts, trainers, money, weapons and other materials to ISS.<ref name=\"vow\" /> The [[United Nations]] also claimed in November 2017 that ISS receives direct assistance from ISIL officials in [[Syria]] and [[Iraq]].{{sfnp
column5: p=30}}<ref name=\"footprint\" /> In smuggling fighters and supplies across the [[Gulf of Aden]], ISS works closely with [[Piracy off the coast of Somalia
column6: Somali pirates]], namely Mohamed Garfanje's Hobyo-Haradhere Piracy Network and another unidentified group that is based in Qandala. These pirates do, however, also supply ISS' rival in Puntland, al-Shabaab, with weapons and other materials.<ref name=\"pirate kings\" />

Furthermore, ISS has been supported by \"financial operative\" Mohamed Mire Ali Yusuf (often simply called Mire Ali) who provided the group with money and supplies through two companies, both located in Bosaso by 2016: Liibaan Trading, a [[Animal husbandry
the Greek myth: livestock trading]] business, and Al-Mutafaq Commercial Company. The [[United States Department of the Treasury]] designated Mire as terrorist and sanctioned his two businesses in February 2018.<ref>{{cite web
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=US terror designations expose 3 international facilitators for Islamic State
column10: title=Treasury Sanctions ISIS Facilitators Across the Globe
column12: work=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]

According to a ''[[New York Times]]'' report, [[Qatar]] may have financed and directed an Islamic State attack in Puntland on 10 May in order to pressure the [[United Arab Emirates]] to end development of a port in Bosaso and to have the contract replaced with Qatar. An influential Qatari businessman named Khalifa al-Muhannadi reportedly claimed Qatari involvement in the attack in a phone call to Qatar's ambassador to the [[Federal Government of Somalia]].<ref>{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=With Guns, Cash and Terrorism, Gulf States Vie for Power in Somalia
column5: date=July 22, 2019}}</ref> Neither Muhannadi nor the ambassador denied the phone call took place, but Qatar claimed al-Muhannadi acted independently while also criticizing the report.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Qatar and Somalia deny NYT's bombing news report

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title = Black Banners in Somalia: The State of al-Shabaab’s Territorial Insurgency and the Specter of the Islamic State
title = The Islamic State in Africa: Estimating Fighter Numbers in Cells Across the Continent
title = A Legitimate Challenger? Assessing the Rivalry between al-Shabaab and the Islamic State in Somalia
title = Sub-Saharan Africa’s Three \"New\" Islamic State Affiliates
title = Reigniting the Rivalry: The Islamic State in Somalia vs. al-Shabaab
title = Islamic State's Mixed Fortunes Become Visible in Somalia

{{Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant}}
[[Category:Factions of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]
[[Category:Factions in the Somali Civil War]]","{{infobox war faction

the Greek myth: caption= The [[Black Standard]] of the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]].

The Labours of Hercules}}: title=Islamic State video promotes Somali arm, incites attacks during holidays

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Islamic State}} [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Yemen Province
column5: Flag of Edward England.svg}} [[Piracy off the coast of Somalia
column8: title=CNN Exclusive: Somali pirate kings are under investigation for helping ISIS and al-Shabaab

The '''Islamic State in Somalia''' (short: '''ISS''') or '''Abnaa ul-Calipha''' is an [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]]-affiliated group that primarily operates in the mountainous areas of [[Puntland]], though has also claimed responsibility for several terrorist attacks throughout the rest of [[Somalia]]. Led by Sheikh [[Abdul Qadir Mumin]], the group is estimated to have up to 300 active fighters. Since its formation, ISS probably managed to take control of a small, sparsely populated territory in northern Somalia's mountainous hinterland, though it was not acknowledged as [[ISIL territorial claims
the Greek myth: official province]] (\"Wilayat\") by ISIL's central leadership until December 2017. Since then, it has sometimes been called '''Somalia Province''' (\"Wilayat al Somal\") by pro-ISIL media. ISS is also the declared enemy of [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: al-Shabaab]], which considers the Islamic State a significant threat to its own predominance among Jihadist factions in Somalia.

The origins of the Islamic State in Somalia trace back to 2012, when [[Abdul Qadir Mumin]] was sent by the al-Shabaab leadership to its remote outpost in Puntland, far from the insurgent group's primary areas of operation in southern Somalia. As cleric with little military experience, Mumin's role in Puntland was originally to attract recruits for the numerical small and militarily weak local al-Shabaab group, which was led by [[Mohamed Said Atom]] at the time. In course of the [[Galgala campaign]] in 2014, however, Atom defected to the government, and Mumin was forced to take control of the Puntland group. Isolated in the remote north and feeling increasingly distanced from al-Shabaab, Mumin began to consider himself more and more independent.{{sfnp
Meanwhile, the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant had launched a propaganda campaign to convince al-Shabaab to join to them, which was \"angrily refused\" by al-Shabaab's central leadership.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=30}} Despite this, several groups of al-Shabaab members found ISIL's ideology attractive or saw this new Jihadist organization as a way to challenge al-Shabaab's leadership at the time. Thus, several small pro-ISIL groups emerged in southern Somalia. This was however not tolerated by the Somali organization, which released statements condemning dissenters{{efn
column6: Al-Shabaab radio stations for example declared in November 2015: \"If anyone says he belongs to another Islamic movement [other than that of al-Qa'ida], kill him on the spot ... we will cut the throat of anyone ... if they undermine unity.\" Al-Shabaab spokesman Ali Mahmud Rage similarly claimed that dissenters in the organization were \"infidels\" who would be \"burnt in hell\".{{sfnp
column10: p=28}} }} and ordered its internal security service Amniyat to arrest or kill pro-ISIL elements such as Hussein Abdi Gedi's faction in [[Middle Juba]].{{sfnp

Mumin, however, long dissatisfied with his situation, pledged ''[[bay'ah]]'' to [[Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi]] and the Islamic State in October 2015. This caused a violent split within Puntland's al-Shabaab, as only 20 of the 300 local Islamist fighters joined Mumin,{{sfnp
column6: title=Islamic State in Somalia claims capture of port town
column10: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> while the al-Shabaab loyalists attempted to kill these defectors. Mumin's small group proceeded to form ''Abnaa ul-Calipha'', better known as ''Islamic State in Somalia'', and to evade their erstwhile comrades, while recruiting new members for their cause.<ref name=\"vow\">{{cite web
column12: title=Somali Officials Vow to Retake Puntland Town
column16: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> Al-Baghdadi and the ISIL leadership did not acknowledge Mumin's bay'ah, instead choosing to wait and see how the Islamic State in Somalia fared.{{sfnp
column19: p=30}} While Mumin's group in the north thus managed to survive, the situation of pro-ISIL forces in southern Somalia consequently became even more precarious. In two notable incidents in November and December 2015, al-Shabaab attacked and destroyed two of the most important southern ISIL cells, namely the ones of Bashir Abu Numan and Mohammad Makkawi Ibrahim. Pro-government forces such as the [[Somali Armed Forces]] and [[Ahlu Sunna Waljama'a]] also claimed to have targeted southern ISIL groups. As result, ISIL forces in southern Somialia remained very weak,{{sfnp
column23: pp=28, 29}} and those that survived appear to have accepted Mumin's authority over time, formally becoming part of ISS.{{sfnp
column27: pp=27, 28}} As result, the \"disparate clump of pro-Islamic State cells\" in Somalia transformed into an \"organized group\".{{sfnp

=== Rise in power and Qandala campaign ===

The Labours of Hercules}}: A variant of the Islamic State in Somalia's usual [[Black Standard
column5: black flag]], which is also sometimes used by the group.<ref name=\"camp\">{{cite web
column7: title=Islamic State highlights ‘first camp of the Caliphate in Somalia’

In March 2016, an ISS cell in southern Puntland was pursued by al-Shabaab fighters into [[Mudug]]; the pursuers were however attacked and completely defeated by the [[Puntland Dervish Force]] and [[Military of Galmudug
the Greek myth: Galmudug soldiers]], thus unintentionally allowing the Islamic State militants to escape into safety.<ref name=\"puntland state\">{{cite web
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=The Islamic State Threat in Somalia’s Puntland State
column9: accessdate=13 July 2017}}</ref> From this point onwards, ISS and al-Shabaab temporarily ceased fighting each other with the exception of some isolated incidents.{{sfnp
column12: p=30}} Over the following months Mumin's followers built up their strength, and by April 2016 they had set up a temporary training camp named after Bashir Abu Numan, the ISIL follower mentioned above who had been killed by al-Shabaab in November 2015.<ref name=\"camp\" />{{sfnp
column16: p=29}} In one of the group's propaganda videos, Mumin blessed the makeshift base as the \"first camp of the Caliphate in Somalia\". On 25 April, ISS also carried out its first attack on government forces, when one of its fighters detonated an [[Improvised explosive device
column17: IED]] against an [[African Union Mission to Somalia
column18: AMISOM]] vehicle in [[Mogadishu]].<ref name=\"camp\" /> By August 2016, Mumin's cell still remained very small, probably under 100 militants, and was not yet very active. According to the [[United States Department of State]], however, ISS began to expand in size by abducting and indoctrinating boys between 10 and 15 and employing them as [[Military use of children
column21: title=US adds Islamic State commander in Somalia to list of global terrorists

By October 2016, ISS had claimed less than one dozen attacks overall since its foundation, showing that the group was still relatively weak. Nevertheless, the fact that many of these strikes had taken place in Mogadishu, indicated that ISS had become able to operate throughout wider Somalia, not just in its core regions in Puntland.<ref name=\"port town\" /> Experts also estimated that Mumin's cell had significantly grown to up to 300 fighters. On 26 October, the group eventually launched their first major operation by [[Qandala campaign
the Greek myth: targeting]] the major port town of [[Qandala]]. The town had both symbolic as well as strategic significance, as it could allow ISS to bolster their local support and receive more supplies from Yemen. The Islamic State fighters managed to overrun the town, meeting little resistance, and thereafter controlled it largely unchallenged until 3 December. On that day, the [[Puntland Security Force]] launched a counter-offensive, and after sporadic fighting for four days, retook Qandala on 7 December 2016.<ref name=\"vow\" /><ref name=\"retake\">{{cite web
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=Forces Retake Somali Town Held by Pro-Islamic State Fighters
column11: p=30}} Mumin's men were forced to retreat to El Ladid, a village 30 kilometers south of Qandala, where government forces once again attacked and scattered them on 18 December.<ref name=\"base\">{{cite web
column13: title=Regional Somali Forces 'Destroy' Islamic State Base
column17: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> Overall, ISS suffered numerous casualties during the Qandala campaign,<ref name=\"retake\" /> but had scored a symbolic victory nonetheless, having captured and held a major town for more than a month.{{sfnp
column20: p=30}} Having established a new headquarters in the al-Mishkat Mountains, ISS subsequently managed to attract new recruits, mostly children and orphans, though also some new defectors from al-Shabaab.<ref name=\"growing threat\">{{cite web
column22: title=The growing threat of Islamic State in Somalia
column26: accessdate=13 July 2017}}</ref> It also became generally more active.{{sfnp

=== Expanded terrorist attacks and announcement of Wilayat al Somal ===

The Labours of Hercules}}: ISS launched an unsuccessful attack on the Village Hotel in [[Bosaso]] in February 2017 ]]

The Qandala campaign resulted in the Puntland government as well as the [[African Union]] taking ISS more seriously, with both taking more steps to counter ISS' growing strength.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=30}} In addition, ISS began to cooperate with al-Shabaab to a limited degree during the subsequent months.{{sfnp
column7: p=33}} On 8 February 2017, ISS launched its next major attack in Puntland, with several militants of the group attacking the Village Hotel in [[Bosaso]]. A fierce shootout ensued, with the hotel's guards eventually repelling the attackers. At least four guards and two ISS fighters died during the fighting.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Islamic State claims hotel attack in northern Somalia
column13: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> On 28 March 2017, ISS [[List of terrorist incidents in March 2017
column14: ambushed]] a convoy of Puntland soldiers near Qandala. The attackers retreated into the hills after inflicting two casualties on the government forces.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=One soldier killed, one wounded by roadside bomb in Somalia's Puntland
column21: accessdate=31 March 2017}}</ref> On 16 April, the group occupied Dasan village near Qandala, though abandoned it again after a few hours.<ref name=\"growing threat\" /> ISS was also blamed for a roadside bomb in [[Galgala]] on 23 April that killed 8 soldiers and injured 3 others.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Roadside bomb in Somalia kills 8 soldiers
column26: accessdate=25 April 2017}}</ref> On 23 May 2017, ISS carried out a suicide bombing, which was possibly the group's very first [[suicide attack]]. When the ISS suicide bomber tried to close in on the Juba Hotel in Bosaso, he was stopped at a military checkpoint, causing him to detonate his explosives, killing five and wounding twelve.<ref>{{cite web
column28: title=Islamic State claims suicide bombing in Somalia
column34: title=Suicide bomber kills five in Somalia's northern Puntland region

In June 2017, a Puntland military official claimed that ISS had been reduced to around 70 active fighters, and sustained itself by stealing food and livestock from local communities.<ref name=\"surrender\">{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Somalia: ISIS fighter surrenders to Puntland authorities
column7: accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> Regional expert [[Matthew Bryden]], on the other side, said that ISS still had up to 300 fighters and had become entrenched in the eastern Galaga mountains, where it had gained the support of some local communities which felt ignored by the government.<ref name=\"Vow Revenge\">{{cite web
column9: title=Somali Officials Condemn Attacks, Vow Revenge
column13: accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref> Observers also noted that ISS had significantly increased their output of propaganda material in an attempt to sway disenfranchised locals<ref name=\"growing threat\" /> and international jihadists to their side.<ref name=\"British jihadi\">{{cite web
column15: title=British jihadi bids to be leader of Islamic State
column19: accessdate=7 August 2017}}</ref> By late 2017, the [[United Nations]] estimated that Mumin's group was about 200 fighters strong.<ref name=\"footprint\">{{cite web
column21: title=Islamic State's footprint spreading in northern Somalia: U.N.

In November 2017, the [[United States]] launched their first airstrikes on ISS, reportedly killing several members of the group<ref>{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=US launches first airstrikes against ISIS in Somalia
column10: title=US targets Islamic State in northeastern Somalia
column15: accessdate=30 December 2017}}</ref> in Buqo Valley, east of Bosaso. They failed to kill Mumin, however, who had been the main target of the bombings.<ref name=\"Survives Strike\">{{cite web
column17: title=Somali Pro-IS Group Chief Survives US Strike, Says Regional Leader
column21: accessdate=10 September 2018 }}</ref> Observers noted that these airstrikes indicated that the US military had come to see ISS as considerable threat to the stability of the region.<ref name=\"footprint\"/> On 25 December, ISIL released an [[Persecution of Christians
column22: anti-Christian]] propaganda video under the name \"Hunt Them Down, O Monotheists\", in which the Islamic State in Somalia was called Wilayat al Somal (Somalia Province), thus seemingly elevating the group to an official province of the proclaimed worldwide caliphate of ISIL.<ref name=\"holidays\"/> Since then, however, the new name has not been consistently applied to the group by pro-ISIL media.{{sfnp

[[File:Puntland Police on Alert as Somalia Terror Threat Moves North.webm
The Labours of Hercules}}: March 2018 ''[[Voice of America]]'' report about the activities of ISS and [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)

Meanwhile, ISS started to launch assassination attempts in the region around Mogadishu from November 2017, with the town [[Afgooye]] most affected.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=16}} From then on, the group greatly increased its rate of attacks on government targets.{{sfnp
column7: p=30}} By May 2018, ISS had reportedly carried out eleven attacks and killed 23 people who had allegedly worked for the government, such as intelligence agents, soldiers, officials, and policemen. In response to these assaults, the [[National Intelligence and Security Agency]] started to arrest suspected ISS members in and around Mogadishu.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Analysis: Islamic State ramps up attack claims in Somalia
column15: title=Somali intelligence agency arrests two Islamic State members in Mogadishu
column19: accessdate=14 June 2018 }}</ref> ISS also abducted nine people in the region around Qandala in January 2018, including some off-duty soldiers. The militia later tortured and decapitated at least three of them, leaving them along a road to be found by passersby.<ref>{{cite web
column21: title=Decapitated bodies found in Somalia days after 'Islamic State' abductions
column25: accessdate=14 June 2018 }}</ref> At the end of 2018, ISS claimed to have carried out 66 attacks, more than in 2016 and 2017 combined.{{sfnp

column5: quote=As we record these crimes, we do not do so as a complaint or out of weakness, but to teach people, especially our people in Somalia, what the al Qaeda branch in Somalia has done, because the response from the Islamic State is coming.
column6: source=—Islamic State in Somalia warning to [[Al-Shabaab (militant group)

The group also grew more sophisticated and further expanded its presence throughout Somalia. It had begun to collect taxes (essentially [[Protection racket
the Greek myth: protection money]]) on businesses in Bosaso by August 2018, greatly increasing its revenue.{{sfnp
column5: p=30}} At some point in 2018, ISS managed to convince a significant number of al-Shabaab militants to defect, resulting in the formation of an Islamic State cell in [[Beledweyne]].{{sfnp
column8: pp=30–31}} As result of its increasing activity in central and southern Somalia, the rivalry between ISS and al-Shabaab reignited in full, with several clashes occurring between the groups. In October 2018, al-Shabaab probably executed ISS depuy Mahad Maalin in Mogadishu,{{sfnp
column11: p=31}} while Islamic State forces ambushed an al-Shabaab group near B'ir Mirali southwest of Qandala, reportedly killing 14 rival militants.{{sfnp
column14: p=32}} The growing violence between the two jihadist rebel factions resulted in al-Shabaab central command releasing a speech as well as an 18-page treatise on 20 December 2018. In these works, the Islamic State  was sharply rebuked as corrupt, apostate, and seditionist force, while al-Shabaab authorized its loyalists to destroy ISS elements as \"disease in the Jihad\". This amounted to an official [[declaration of war]].{{sfnp

In the next months, the two factions greatly increased their attacks against each other: They clashed near [[El Adde]] in December 2018, and at numerous locations in Puntland between January and March 2019. ISS reportedly suffered one major setback during these clashes when it lost one of its main bases in the Dasaan area to al-Shabaab.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=32}} Regardless, neither organizations appears to have suffered to a tangible degree from this inter-rebel fighting, and both have continued to strike government targets.{{sfnp
column7: p=33}} The United States Air Force carried out an airstrike against ISS on 14 April 2019, killing its deputy Abdihakim Mohamed Ibrahim at Xiriiro, Bari region.<ref name=\"no2\">{{cite web
column9: title=US Confirms Airstrike Kills Deputy Leader of IS Militants in Somalia
column13: access-date=17 August 2019}}</ref> On 12 July 2019, ISS militants clashed with security forces near the Safa hotel in Puntland's capital, Bosaso, the same day as an al-Shabaab attack on a hotel in [[Kismayo]].<ref>{{Cite news
column18: access-date=21 July 2019}}</ref> The United States Air Force bombed an ISS base in the [[Golis Mountains]] on 8 May 2019, reportedly killing 13 militants.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=US airstrike kills 13 Somalia ISIS fighters, AFRICOM says

On 27 October 2019, ISIL Caliph Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi was killed in the [[Barisha raid]], whereupon the organisation's central command elected [[Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi]] as new leader. On 4 November, the Islamic State in Somalia officially pledged allegiance to al-Qurashi.{{sfnp
column6: title=US Takes Notice as More Islamic State Branches Back New Leader
column12: title=Somali ISIS affiliate swears allegiance to new leader
column15: access-date=2019-11-04}}</ref> By this time, ISS was regarded as important element in ISIL's international network, but still suffered from an inability to expand due to pressure by  al-Shabaab, the Somali Armed Forces, and the [[United States Armed Forces]]. From late 2019, the group consequently attempted to become more active beyond Somalia's borders, as its forces tried to infiltrate Ethiopia and recruit new forces there.{{sfnp
column18: pp=5–6}} Its operations in Ethiopia were repeatedly crushed by local security forces, and several militants were arrested.{{sfnp
column23: title=Islamic State trains in Somalia's Puntland
column27: accessdate=19 March 2020 }}</ref> ISS had also set up a new training camp, codenamed \"Dawoud al Somali\", probably in northern Puntland.<ref name=\"trains\" />

The Labours of Hercules}}: ISS is primarily active in the eastern Galaga Mountains, which mostly lie in the Bari region of [[Puntland]].]]

The Islamic State in Somalia is led by Abdul Qadir Mumin, whose role for the continued existence of the group has been judged to be extremely important.{{sfnp
column5: p=31}} Described as \"eloquent and persuasive, [...] very savvy and sophisticated\", Mumin is deeply involved in international jihadism and considered to be an extremely dangerous terrorist leader. After reports circulated in June/July 2017 that Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi had been killed, terror expert Candyce Kelshall even speculated that Mumin might be tempted to declare himself the new caliph of ISIL.<ref name=\"British jihadi\" /> Mumin's direct control is however limited to ISS forces in northern Somalia. Though pro-ISIL cells in the southern parts of the country have probably accepted Mumin as their official leader,{{sfnp
column9: pp=27, 28}} the exact relationship between the northern and southern groups of ISS remains unclear. It is possible that the latter only have nominal links to the northern branch or no actual contact at all.{{sfnp
column13: p=28}} In any case, the southern cells remain mostly weak and exist in a precarious state, constantly threatened by al-Shabaab.{{sfnp

Besides Mumin, two other ISS commanders were known: Mahad Maalin served as field commander<ref name=\"retake\"/> and deputy of the group until his death in October 2018.{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=30}} He was succeeded as deputy by Abdihakim Mohamed Ibrahim, alias \"Dhoqob\", who was believed to be Mumin's \"right-hand man\". Dhoqob was killed on 14 April 2019, and his death was portrayed by the [[United States Africa Command]] as major blow to ISS.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=US confirms killing No.2 Islamic State leader in Somalia

column5: p=30}} that ISS controls a relatively small territory in Puntland's mountainous hinterland,<ref name=\"Vow Revenge\" /> the group is not known to have attempted to set up something resembling a government at any point of its existence. ISS' current areas are only very sparsely settled or not populated at all,{{sfnp
column9: p=30}} while Qandala's civilian population completely fled during its occupation by the militants.<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=Last Resident Leaves Somali Town Taken by Islamic State
column15: accessdate=10 February 2017}}</ref> By November 2019, ISS controlled the villages of Dhasaan and Shebaab in Bari region.<ref>{{cite web
column17: title=Letter dated 1 November 2019 from the Chair of the Security Council Committee pursuant to resolution 751 (1992) concerning Somalia addressed to the President of the Security Council
column19: date=1 November 2019}}</ref> The group is known to use caves as hiding places.<ref name=\"Survives Strike\"/>

The strength of the Islamic State in Somalia fluctuated over time, and is not known with certainty. Mumin's initial cell was estimated at about 20 members, growing to less than 100 by August 2016. At the time of the Qandala campaign, a former [[Puntland Intelligence Agency]] official argued that ISS counted 200 to 300 militants. Following its defeat at Qandala, local observers judged that the group declined to just 70–150 members by June 2017.{{sfnp
column5: p=24}} The Islamic State in Somalia subsequently recruited new fighters to alleviate its manpower shortage, though Somali journalists gave widely different accounts on the success of this recruitment drive. Accordingly, ISS was believed to be between 100 and 300 militants strong by mid-2018.{{sfnp
column9: pp=24–25}} The vast majority of ISS members are Somalis, with only a few [[Mujahideen#Somalia
column10: foreign mujahideen]] fighting for the group, including Sudanese, a Yemenis,{{sfnp
column14: p=30}}<ref name=\"footprint\" /> Ethiopians,<ref name=\"holidays\"/> and Egyptians.{{sfnp

The propaganda of ISS is generally extremely inferior compared to its direct rival al-Shabaab. The Islamic State in Somalia initially had no media wing of its own and also has not organized a \"robust informal media presence\".{{sfnp
column5: p=31}} Instead, it mostly relies on the existing propaganda channels of ISIL, such as the [[Amaq News Agency]],{{sfnp
column12: p=31}} the ''Global Front to Support the Islamic State'', and the media arms of other ISIL branches in [[Iraq]], [[Syria]], [[Yemen]], [[Egypt]], and [[Libya]].{{sfnp
column15: p=29}} The propaganda video of December 2017 that declared ISS a province, however, also claimed to have been produced by the \"Media Office of Wilayat al Somal\".<ref name=\"holidays\"/> In late 2019, ISS began releasing propaganda in [[Amharic]], a language widely spoken in Ethiopia, in an attempt to attract new recruits there.{{sfnp

the Greek myth: Piracy off the coast of Somalia}}

In its endeavor to build up its military strength, the Islamic State in Somalia is aided by the fact that Puntland's government has only limited control over its hinterland while its military is overstrechted. Peripheral areas are thus mostly ignored by the security forces and instead run by rebellious and infighting tribal militias. As result, local clans (including Mumin's own, the [[Majeerteen]] Ali Saleban) are aggrieved by their perceived marginalisation by the government and in some cases ready to support ISS. Such dissatisfied elements are the ones from which ISS receives supplies and recruits new members.<ref name=\"puntland state\" /><ref name=\"growing threat\" />{{sfnp
The Labours of Hercules}}: p=30}} There have also been accounts, however, that ISS raids those communities which do not supply it with food and other necessities,<ref name=\"surrender\" /> and to kidnap children in order to indoctrinate and train them as child soldiers.<ref name=\"list global\" /> The group is also known to collect taxes in areas which it controls or at least influences.{{sfnp

The group is also directly supported by the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Yemen Province]], which is known to have sent experts, trainers, money, weapons and other materials to ISS.<ref name=\"vow\" /> The [[United Nations]] also claimed in November 2017 that ISS receives direct assistance from ISIL officials in [[Syria]] and [[Iraq]].{{sfnp
column5: p=30}}<ref name=\"footprint\" /> In smuggling fighters and supplies across the [[Gulf of Aden]], ISS works closely with [[Piracy off the coast of Somalia
column6: Somali pirates]], namely Mohamed Garfanje's Hobyo-Haradhere Piracy Network and another unidentified group that is based in Qandala. These pirates do, however, also supply ISS' rival in Puntland, al-Shabaab, with weapons and other materials.<ref name=\"pirate kings\" />

Furthermore, ISS has been supported by \"financial operative\" Mohamed Mire Ali Yusuf (often simply called Mire Ali) who provided the group with money and supplies through two companies, both located in Bosaso by 2016: Liibaan Trading, a [[Animal husbandry
the Greek myth: livestock trading]] business, and Al-Mutafaq Commercial Company. The [[United States Department of the Treasury]] designated Mire as terrorist and sanctioned his two businesses in February 2018.<ref>{{cite web
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=US terror designations expose 3 international facilitators for Islamic State
column10: title=Treasury Sanctions ISIS Facilitators Across the Globe
column12: work=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]

According to a ''[[New York Times]]'' report, [[Qatar]] may have financed and directed an Islamic State attack in Puntland on 10 May in order to pressure the [[United Arab Emirates]] to end development of a port in Bosaso and to have the contract replaced with Qatar. An influential Qatari businessman named Khalifa al-Muhannadi reportedly claimed Qatari involvement in the attack in a phone call to Qatar's ambassador to the [[Federal Government of Somalia]].<ref>{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=With Guns, Cash and Terrorism, Gulf States Vie for Power in Somalia
column5: date=July 22, 2019}}</ref> Neither Muhannadi nor the ambassador denied the phone call took place, but Qatar claimed al-Muhannadi acted independently while also criticizing the report.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Qatar and Somalia deny NYT's bombing news report

title = The Islamic State in Africa: Estimating Fighter Numbers in Cells Across the Continent

title = Sub-Saharan Africa’s Three \"New\" Islamic State Affiliates
title = Reigniting the Rivalry: The Islamic State in Somalia vs. al-Shabaab

Changed \slogan\" to \"phrase.\"  The word slogan was used a lot in the first few paragraphs.",safe,Steveok1,"{{Use American English

the Greek myth: image1 = Official Portrait of President Reagan 1981-cropped.jpg

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Trump's MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN! sign used during his 2016 presidential campaign]]
A button from Reagan's 1980 presidential campaign]]

\"'''Make America Great Again'''\" (often abbreviated as '''MAGA''') is a [[campaign slogan]] used in [[American politics]] that was popularized by [[Donald Trump]] in his successful [[Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign
the Greek myth: 2016 presidential campaign]]. [[Ronald Reagan]] used the similar slogan \"'''Let's make America great again'''\" in his successful [[Ronald Reagan 1980 presidential campaign

[[Bill Clinton]] also used the phrase in speeches during his successful [[Bill Clinton 1992 presidential campaign
the Greek myth: 1992 presidential campaign]] and again in a radio commercial aired for his wife [[Hillary Clinton 2008 presidential campaign
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Hillary Clinton's 2008 presidential primary campaign]]. Democratic pollster [[Douglas Schoen]] has called Trump's use of the phrase as \"probably the most resonant campaign slogan in recent history\", citing large majorities of Americans who believed the country was in decline.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Donald Trump saw what politicians ignored. And then he disrupted American politics
column13: title=Americans Aren't Sure Anything In America Works Anymore
column18: accessdate=November 5, 2018}}</ref> The slogan has become a [[pop culture]] phenomenon, seeing widespread use and spawning numerous variants in the arts, entertainment, and politics, and used both by those who support and oppose the presidency of Donald Trump.

In the Trump era, a [[Voice of America]] [[Analytic journalism
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: loaded]], because it \"doesn't just appeal to people who hear it as racist [[Dog-whistle politics
The Labours of Hercules}}: coded language]], but also those who have felt a loss of status as other groups have become more empowered.\"<ref>{{cite news
column12: language=en}}</ref> However, others have denied this, claiming that the slogan refers to \"making America an economic powerhouse, a military powerhouse, pride in being an American.\"<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Are Trump's MAGA hats racist? Here's what Freep readers have to say

\"Let's make America great again\" was first used in [[Ronald Reagan]]'s 1980 presidential campaign. At the time the United States was suffering from a worsening economy at home marked by [[stagflation]] and Reagan, using the country's economic distress as a springboard for his campaign, used the slogan to stir a sense of patriotism among the electorate.<ref>{{cite news
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Ronald Reagan's 1980 Campaign Poster, \"Let's Make America Great Again\"
column11: title=Ronald Reagan's Classic 1980 Campaign Poster Challenges Voters, \"Let's Make America Great Again\"
column16: title=Donald Trump Claims Authorship of Legendary Reagan Slogan; Has Never Heard of Google
column27: url-status=dead}}</ref> Within his acceptance speech at the [[1980 Republican National Convention]], Reagan said, \"For those without job opportunities, we’ll stimulate new opportunities, particularly in the inner cities where they live. For those who’ve abandoned hope, we’ll restore hope and we’ll welcome them into a great national crusade to make America great again.\"<ref>{{cite web
column29: title = Acceptance of the Republican Nomination for President: July 17, 1980
column35: title = Tear Down this Wall: The Reagan Revolution - a National Review History

The phrase was also used in speeches<ref>{{cite web
the Greek myth: title=Make America Great Again a Retrospective
The Labours of Hercules}}: accessdate=July 21, 2017}}</ref> by [[Bill Clinton]] during his 1992 presidential campaign; however, it was not a slogan of the campaign.<ref>{{cite news
column7: title=Who really first came up with the phrase 'Make America Great Again'?
column11: accessdate=September 10, 2016}}</ref> Clinton also used the phrase in a radio commercial aired for [[Hillary Clinton 2008 presidential campaign
column12: Hillary Clinton's 2008 presidential primary campaign]].<ref>{{cite web
column13: title=2008 Clinton Campaign Ad: Bill Clinton: Hillary Will \"Make America Great Again\"

During the [[2016 United States presidential election
the Greek myth: 2016 electoral campaign]], Clinton suggested that Trump's version, used as a campaign rallying cry, was a message to white Southerners that Trump was promising to \"give you an economy you had 50 years ago, and ... move you back up on the social totem pole and other people down.\"<ref>{{cite news
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Bill Clinton suggests Trump slogan racist – but he used the same one

The Labours of Hercules}}: [[Donald Trump]] wearing a ''MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN'' cap during his 2016 campaign]]

On September 16, 2011, [[Roger Stone]], Trump's longtime political advisor and a veteran of Reagan's 1980 campaign, tweeted the slogan: \"Make America Great Again --TRUMP HUCKABEE 2012  #nomormons\".<ref>{{cite tweet
column6: title=Make America Great Again -- TRUMP HUCKABEE 2012}}</ref> Two months later, in December 2011, Trump made a statement in which he said he was unwilling to rule out running as a presidential candidate in the future, explaining \"I must leave all of my options open because, above all else, we must make America great again.\"<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Trump was saying 'Make America Great Again' long before he claims he thought it up
column14: accessdate=November 5, 2018}}</ref> Also in December 2011, he published [[Time to Get Tough
column15: a book]] using as a subtitle the similar phrase \"Making America #1 Again\" — which in a 2015 reissue would be changed to \"Make America Great Again!\"<ref>{{cite news
column18: title=Book Party: Donald Trump's 'Time to Get Tough' is out in paperback. You'll never guess the new subtitle.

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Trump popularized the slogan \"Make America Great Again\" by stitching it onto his widely distributed cap.

Trump himself began using the slogan formally on November 7, 2012, the day after [[2012 United States presidential election
the Greek myth: Barack Obama won his reelection against Mitt Romney]]. By his own account, Trump first considered \"We Will Make America Great\", but did not feel like it had the right \"ring\" to it. \"Make America Great\" was his next slogan idea, but upon further reflection, he felt that it was a slight to America because it implied that America was never great. After selecting \"Make America Great Again\", Trump immediately had an attorney register it. (Trump later said that he was unaware of Reagan's use in 1980 until 2015, but noted that \"he didn't trademark it\".)<ref name=\"tumulty20170118\" /> On November 12 he signed an application with the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] requesting exclusive rights to use the slogan for political purposes. It was registered as a service mark on July 14, 2015, after Trump formally began his [[Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: 2016 presidential campaign]] and demonstrated that he was using the slogan for the purpose stated on the application.<ref name=servicemark>{{cite web
column6: publisher=[[United States Patent and Trademark Office]]
column11: title=How Donald Trump came up with 'Make America Great Again'

[[File:Make America Great Again outdoor banner on roadside in California.jpg
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Banner displaying \"Vote To Make America Great Again\" on a roadside in [[California]] shortly after the November 2016 election]]

[[File:U.S. President Donald Trump with a KAG hat.jpg
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Trump wearing a \"Keep America Great\" hat in December 2019]]

During the campaign, Trump often used the slogan, especially by wearing hats emblazoned with the phrase in white letters, which soon became popular among his supporters.<ref>{{cite news
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=Why Donald Trump has given up on the hat
column8: accessdate=November 5, 2018}}</ref> The slogan was so important to the campaign that at one point it spent more on making the hats – sold for $25 each on its website – than on polling, consultants, or television commercials. The candidate claimed that \"millions\" were sold.{{r
column9: tumulty20170118}} Following Trump's election, the website of [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump
column10: his presidential transition]] was established at greatagain.gov.<ref>{{cite news
column13: title='Great again': Donald Trump's .gov website is now live
column17: accessdate=November 12, 2016}}</ref> President Trump stated in January 2017 that the slogan of his [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2020
column18: 2020 reelection campaign]] would be \"Keep America Great\" and immediately ordered a lawyer to trademark it.{{r
column19: tumulty20170118}} Trump tweeted \"MAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN!\" on September 1, 2018,<ref>{{cite web
column22: accessdate=September 2, 2017}}</ref> apparently in response to [[Meghan McCain]] telling approximately 3,000 mourners at [[John McCain]]'s memorial service, \"The America of John McCain has no need to be made great again because America was always great.\"<ref>{{cite news
column29: title='America was always great': Meghan McCain rebukes Trump

Donald Trump took the campaign slogan to [[social media]] (primarily to [[Twitter]]), using the [[hashtag]]s #makeamericagreatagain and its acronym #maga. In response to criticism regarding his frequent and untraditional usage of social media, Trump defended himself by tweeting \"My use of social media is not Presidential - it's MODERN DAY PRESIDENTIAL. Make America Great Again!\" on July 1, 2017.<ref>{{cite news
The Labours of Hercules}}: title= 'Modern day presidential': Donald Trump defends use of social media in Twitter storm
column11: issn= 0307-1235}}</ref> This comment claimed to justify his usage of social media as his main preferred method of communicating to his supporter-base.

In the first half of 2017 alone, Trump repeated his slogan on Twitter 33 times.<ref name=\":0\">{{cite news
The Labours of Hercules}}: title= 'Great Again' Is Trump's Magic Twitter Mantra
column8: access-date= November 3, 2017}}</ref> In an article for [[Bloomberg News]], Mark Whitehouse noted \"A regression analysis suggests the phrase adds (very roughly) 51,000 to a post's retweet-and-favorite count, which is important given that the average Trump tweet attracts a total of 107,000.\"<ref name=\":0\" />

Trump attributed his victory (in part) to social media when he said \"I won the 2016 election with interviews, speeches, and social media.\"<ref>{{cite news
The Labours of Hercules}}: title= Donald Trump Defends Twitter Use as 'MODERN DAY PRESIDENTIAL'
column9: language= en-US}}</ref> According to RiteTag,<ref>{{cite web
column11: title= #maga Hashtag Analytics {{!}} RiteTag: Find the best hashtags
column16: publisher= RiteKit is a SaaS (Software as a Service) Company for which RiteTag is a subscription-based product.
column18: access-date= 2018-07-18}}</ref> the estimated hourly statistics for #maga on Twitter alone include: 1,304 unique tweets, 5,820,000 hashtag exposure, and 3,424 retweets with 14 % of #maga tweets including images, 55 % including links, and 51 % including mentions.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title= #maga Hashtag Analytics {{!}} RiteTag: Find the best hashtags

Donald Trump set up his Twitter account in March 2009. His follower-count increased significantly following the announcement (June 16, 2015) of his intention to run for president in the [[2016 United States presidential election
the Greek myth: 2016 presidential election]], with particularly notable spikes occurring after his securing the [[Republican Party (United States)
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Republican Party]] nomination (May 3, 2016) and after winning the presidency.<ref>

the Greek myth: title= Donald J. Trump Twitter Followers Statistics - Trackalytics

Political commentator and author [[Peter Beinart]] published a 2006 book titled ''The Good Fight: Why Liberals—and Only Liberals—Can Win the War on Terror and Make America Great Again''<ref>{{cite book
the Greek myth: title=The good fight : why liberals--and only liberals--can win the War on Terror and make America great again
column8: url-access=registration }}</ref> drawing on the philosophy of theologian [[Reinhold Niebuhr]] after the [[Invasion of Iraq]] and early years of the [[War on Terror]].

In 2011, [[Christine O'Donnell]] published a book about her Senate campaign in the [[United States Senate special election in Delaware, 2010
the Greek myth: 2010 Delaware special election]] titled ''Troublemaker: Let's Do What It Takes To Make America Great Again''.<ref>{{cite news

After Donald Trump popularized the use of the phrase, the phrase and [[Snowclone
the Greek myth: modifications of it]] became widely used to refer to his election campaign and his politics. Trump's primary opponents, [[Ted Cruz]] and [[Scott Walker (politician)
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Scott Walker]], began using \"Make America Great Again\" in speeches, inciting Trump to send [[cease-and-desist letter]]s to them. Trump claimed after the election that the hats \"were copied, unfortunately. It was [[knockoff
The Labours of Hercules}}: knocked off]] by 10 to one [...] but it was a slogan, and every time somebody buys one, that's an advertisement.\"{{r
column5: tumulty20170118}} Cruz later sold hats featuring, \"Make Trump Debate Again\", in response to Trump's boycotting the [[Republican Party presidential debates, 2016#January 28, 2016 – Des Moines, Iowa
column8: title=Cruz sells 'Make Trump Debate Again' hats

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: West Michigan retail store launched in December 2019 to sell Trump-related merchandise.]]

the Greek myth: Grand Rapids, Michigan]] reported that a \"MAGA Store\" had opened in December 2019, using the acronym from the Trump campaign's \"Make America Great Again\" slogan.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Man opens 'MAGA' store in Kent County
column11: date=26 December 2019}}</ref> The store subsequently changed its name to The Patriot Store of Grand Rapids as of January 2020.{{cn

New York Governor [[Andrew Cuomo]] stated that America \"was never that great\" during a September 2018 bill signing.<ref>{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=Cuomo says America 'was never that great'
column13: title=Cuomo Says America 'Was Never That Great' in Jab at Trump Slogan
column20: issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Former US Attorney General [[Eric Holder]] questioned the slogan in a March 2019 interview on [[MSNBC]], asking \"Exactly when did you think America was great?\"<ref>{{cite news
column21: title=Holder to Trump: 'Exactly when did you think America was great?'
column26: quote=Holder also discusses the Trump slogan of \"Make America Great Again\", posing the question: \"when did you think America was great?\".}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
column28: title=Eric Holder goes on MAGA attack: 'Exactly when did you think America was great?'

In June 2017, [[Emmanuel Macron]], [[President of France]], rebuked Trump over [[United States withdrawal from the Paris Agreement
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Paris Climate Agreement]]. The last sentence of the speech delivered by him was \"make our planet great again.\"<ref>{{cite web

In October 2018, during [[Prabowo Subianto 2019 presidential campaign
the Greek myth: his campaign]] for the [[2019 Indonesian general election
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: 2019 Indonesian presidential election]], opposition leader [[Prabowo Subianto]] used the phrase \"make Indonesia great again\", though he denied having copied Trump.<ref>{{cite news
column6: title=Prabowo wants to 'make Indonesia great again'

During the [[2019 European Parliament election in Sweden
the Greek myth: Swedish European Parliament election]] in May 2019, the [[Christian Democrats (Sweden)
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Swedish Christian Democratic Party]] used the slogan \"[[Lagom
column12: title=Svenskarnas starka stöd för EU kan inte tas för givet

The Labours of Hercules}}: February 2019 Fridays for Future protest in Berlin with the line ''Make Earth Greta Again''.]]

Members of the [[School strike for climate
the Greek myth: Fridays for Future Movement]] have often used slogans like \"Make Earth Greta Again\", referring to [[Greta Thunberg]].<ref>{{cite web
The Labours of Hercules}}: title=Greta Thunberg tells Rome: They have stolen our future
column8: accessdate=17 June 2019}}</ref> In 2019, [[Grant Armour]] and [[Milene Larsson]] co-directed a documentary film named ''[[Make the World Greta Again]]''.<ref>{{cite web

column5: supergroup]] [[Prophets of Rage]] displaying a \"Make America Rage Again\" stage backdrop reminiscent of the \"Make America Great Again\" catchphrase as it appears on a MAGA hat.]]

The phrase and its variants are widely used and parodied in media. For example:
* A [[Dunk-a-roos]] marketing campaign used the slogan \"Make America Dunk Again\".<ref>{{cite news
The Labours of Hercules}}: title= General Mills hopes to hit sweet spot with new 'Smugglaroos' campaign

* ''[[Make Everything Great Again]]'' is a [[street art]] [[mural]] by artist Mindaugas Bonanu in [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]].<ref>{{citation

* The tagline for ''[[The Purge: Election Year]]'' (2016) is \"Keep America Great\" (a phrase Trump would later use as his 2020 campaign slogan); one of the TV spots for the film featured Americans who explained why they support the Purge, with one stating he does so \"to keep my country [America] great\".<ref>{{cite news

* The video game ''[[Wolfenstein: The New Colossus]]'' (2017) used \"Make America Nazi-Free Again\" in its marketing campaign.<ref>{{cite web

*Rapper [[Kevin Gates]] released a song in 2018 called ''M.A.T.A'', meaning ''Make America [[Trap music
* [[Make America Rock Again]] was a rock concert tour.<ref>{{cite news

the short story collection by Agatha Chr: Public Enemy]] and [[Cypress Hill]], called their 2017 nationwide tour the \"Make America Rage Again Tour\", using a stage backdrop reminiscent of a MAGA hat.

* [[Snoop Dogg]] released a song titled \"[[Make America Crip Again]]\".<ref>{{cite web
