Two strong, long-tracked tornadoes occurred over southern Mississippi. The first occurred between Jackson and Hattiesburg, dealing direct blows or close passes to the towns of [[Bassfield, Mississippi
column5: Heidelberg]]. A second tornado followed a similar path from north of Bassfield, close to [[Collins, Mississippi
column6: Collins]], and northeast toward [[Enterprise, Clarke County, Mississippi
column7: Enterprise]]. Tornado emergencies were issued for both tornadoes, with some communities encompassed in both, a rare occurrence potentially not seen since 1999. According to radar, debris lofted by the two tornadoes exceeded {{convert
column11: abbr=on}} high and may have been carried up to {{convert
column15: abbr=on}} downstream into Alabama. At least 11 fatalities were confirmed, and several homes and businesses were reported damaged or completely destroyed. As the line of storms progressed east, another significant tornado affected [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], prompting yet another tornado emergency.<ref name=\"wapoupdates\">{{cite news
column19: title=13 Dead as Tornadoes, Storms Tear Through Southern States
column23: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> The tornado killed two people,<ref name=\"tn\" /> including one man who died when a tree fell onto his home; numerous other people were treated for injuries at local hospitals.<ref>{{cite web
column24: title=1 killed, dozens injured, 150 homes & businesses damaged after tornado, powerful storms stuck Chattanooga
column28: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> It has been rated EF3 intensity.<ref name=\"EastChatupdate\"/> A pre-dawn tornado in [[Murray County, Georgia]], killed seven people and inflicted injuries to at least 23 others as it hit a number of mobile homes.<ref>{{cite web
column29: title=\"War zone:\" At least 7 dead in Murray County from Sunday's storms, at least 23 injured
column33: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> A man in [[Cartersville, Georgia]], was also killed when a tree fell through his home.<ref>{{cite web
column38: title=At least 6 dead, dozens injured after severe storms rip through Georgia overnight
column42: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> One tornado in [[Seneca, South Carolina]], killed one person. A second in [[Hampton County, South Carolina
column43: Hampton County]] killed five people, three of which were in [[Nixville, South Carolina
column46: title=At Least 6 Dead In South Carolina – 5 In Hampton County – After Violent Tornadoes, Reports Say
column50: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> Further still, a third tornado of EF3 strength killed two people and caused seven injuries in [[Livingston, South Carolina

Heavy rainfall across eastern Texas led to flash flooding and multiple road closures throughout many communities. Downed trees and powerlines caused additional road closures.<ref>{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=NWS confirms EF-1 tornado in Harrison County, damage, flooding reported in several area across East Texas
column7: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> Gusty winds in [[Upshur County, Texas]] killed one man after a tree fell on him in his driveway.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Upshur County man dies after tree falls on him during storm
column13: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> As the storms progressed into Arkansas, widespread damaging winds were observed, causing the collapse of old buildings and the historic [[Centennial Baptist Church]] in downtown [[Helena, Arkansas
column17: title=Strong storms strike Helena-West Helena, Arkansas over Easter weekend
column21: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> The [[9-1-1]] and emergency dispatch were disrupted throughout the city, and scattered debris obstructed ambulances from reaching hospitals.<ref>{{cite web
column23: title=Severe storms bring flooding, high winds and damages to Mid-South
column27: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> The strong winds toppled numerous trees, powerlines, and fences throughout the southern portions of the state.<ref>{{cite web
column28: title=Easter Sunday Arkansas storm damage reports from National Weather Service
column32: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> Additional damage was inflicted to structures such as greenhouses, poultry farms, sheds, barns, and docks. The downed trees blocked numerous highways.<ref name=\"0412rpt\" /> In [[White Hall, Arkansas
column33: White Hall]], one downed tree fell onto a home and killed an occupant. More than 143,000 customers were left without power in Arkansas in the storms' wake.<ref name=\"ardeath\">{{cite web
column34: title=1 dead after tree falls on home in White Hall
column38: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> In Mississippi, heavy rainfall overspread [[Panola County, Mississippi
column39: Panola County]], where Mississippi Emergency Management Personnel donated sandbags to prevent flooding.<ref>{{cite web
column40: title=Panola County hit by severe floods
column54: abbr=on}}, across northern Alabama prompted significant flooding across [[DeKalb County, Alabama
column55: DeKalb County]]. There, about 50 roadways were temporarily closed. Floodwaters inundated some businesses in [[Collinsville, Alabama
column57: Fort Payne]], waters inundated several businesses, forcing about 35 people from the flooded areas. Multiple roads were reportedly washed out.<ref>{{cite news
column59: title=Flood waters damage DeKalb bridges, homes and businesses
column63: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> Significant flooding was likewise reported across [[Madison County, Alabama
column68: title=Storm Damage, Flooding Reported across North America

A person was killed by a fallen tree in Davidson, North Carolina.<ref>{{cite news
the Greek myth: title=Storms tear through US south, leaving at least 20 people dead

On the night of April 12, [[state of emergency]] declarations were issued in Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama.<ref>{{cite web
the short story collection by Agatha Chr: title=6 dead, half a million without power as storms batter South
column7: accessdate=April 13, 2020}}</ref> More than 1.3 million customers from Texas into Pennsylvania lost power at the height of the storm.<ref name=\"wapoupdates\" /> Widespread damage in Seneca, South Carolina, prompted a curfew for the city.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=City of Seneca says curfew will go into effect Monday night following deadly storms

*[[Tornado outbreak of April 23, 2000]] – Another tornado outbreak that occurred on Easter Sunday in 2000
